{{about|the artist and comedian|the chef|Jess Tom}} {{Infobox artist | name = Jess Thom | image = Jess Thom by Laura Page.jpg | caption = Portrait of Jess Thom taken by Laura Page | birth_name = Jessica Thom | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|07|14|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[London]], England | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = British | movement = [[Disability art]] | awards = Total Theatre Award, Best Emerging Company | patrons = | imagesize = | field = Theatre, Comedy | training = [[Royal College of Art]] | influenced by = | influenced = }} '''Jessica Thom''' (born 14 July 1980) is a British theatre-maker and comedian best known for Touretteshero, an alter-ego and project aimed at increasing awareness of [[Tourette syndrome|Tourette's Syndrome,]] the neurological condition which she was diagnosed with in her early twenties.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2014/jul/09/jess-thom-tourettes-hero-comedy|title=Jess Thom AKA Touretteshero: comedy at its most unpredictable|last=Caird|first=Jo|date=2014-07-09|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} The first Touretteshero production, ''Backstage in Biscuit Land'' debuted at [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe|Edinburgh Fringe Festival]] in 2014. The show won critical acclaim and has since toured across the UK and internationally, including various performances across North America{{Cite web|url=http://www.britishcouncil.us/tourettesheros-backstage-biscuit-land|title=Touretteshero's Backstage in Biscuit Land {{!}} British Council|website=www.britishcouncil.us|language=en|access-date=2017-02-21}} and Australia.{{Cite news|url=https://www.festival.melbourne/2016/events/backstage-in-biscuit-land/|title=Backstage in Biscuit Land {{!}} Melbourne Festival, 06—23 October 2016.|newspaper=Melbourne Festival|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en}} Thom has also made numerous appearances on British television, notably an interview on ''[[Russell Howard's Good News|Russel Howard's Good News]]'' which has garnered more than 400,000 YouTube views{{Citation|last=Russell Howard's Good News|title=Russell speaks to real life hero Jess Thom|date=2015-10-30|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i8gOcbneQRQ|accessdate=2017-02-21}} {{As of|2017|February|lc=y}}, and was reported on by ''[[The Independent]]'' and ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' newspapers.{{Cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/10/31/biscuits-this-woman-explains-living-with-tourettes-in-hilarious-and-heart-warming-interview-on-russell-howards-good-news-5473598/|title=This woman explains living with Tourette's in funny and heart-warming interview|last=Metro.co.uk|first=Katie Baillie for|date=2015-10-31|website=Metro|access-date=2017-02-21}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.indy100.com/article/this-russell-howard-interview-destigmatising-tourettes-is-very-very-funny--WJm3Q1NF_e|title=This Russell Howard interview destigmatising Tourettes is wickedly|date=2015-10-31|newspaper=indy100|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en-GB}} == Early/personal life == Thom was born in London. She experienced involuntary vocal and physical tics throughout her childhood as a result of Tourette's Syndrome, but was not diagnosed with the condition until her early twenties. Thom has recurring vocal tics, the most common of which is the word 'biscuit' which she can utter up to 16,000 times a day.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/oct/18/backstage-in-biscuit-land-review-tourettes-makes-for-unpredictable-joyous-must-watch-theatre|title=Backstage in Biscuit Land review – Tourette's makes for unpredictable, joyous, must-watch theatre|last=Harmon|first=Steph|date=2016-10-18|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} She has a younger sister, who Jess previously referred to as 'Fat Sister' in a vocal tic whilst she was dieting. Thom acknowledges that her condition presents challenges but seeks to avoid 'self-pity or mockery' and to 'celebrate the creativity and humour of Tourette's'.{{Cite news|url=https://www.touretteshero.com/faq/|title=FAQ|newspaper=Touretteshero|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en-GB}} According to guidance notes for journalists written by the team at Touretteshero, and published by the Guardian:
Although some aspects of [Tourette's Syndrome] are challenging, Jess does not describe herself as a 'Tourette's sufferer' under any circumstances. Instead she likes to be referred to as a 'person with Tourette's' or as simply as 'having Tourette's'. She is 'brave' for all sorts of reasons, but not because she is disabled.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/feb/29/challenging-stereotypes-about-tourette-syndrome|title=Challenging stereotypes about Tourette syndrome|date=2016-02-29|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}
Thom has stated that she finds herself talking about and explaining Tourette's everyday in her day-to-day interactions: "It doesn't always feel like a choice, more a tool for living...Often this is very functional, like explaining at the start of a phone call that I have Tourettes, answering a question or addressing sniggers on public transport."{{Cite web|url=http://exeuntmagazine.com/features/reclaiming-cultural-spaces-a-dialogue/|title=Reclaiming Cultural Spaces: A Dialogue - Exeunt Magazine|website=exeuntmagazine.com|access-date=2017-02-21}} Thom regularly experiences discrimination as a result of having Tourette's. She has recounted one particularly bad experience in multiple interviews, when she went to see comedian [[Mark Thomas]] perform at Tricycle Theatre.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/aug/09/backstage-in-biscuit-land-edinburgh-festival-2014-review-tourettes|title=Edinburgh festival 2014 review: Backstage in Biscuit Land – Tourette's and theatre make a joyous combo|last=Gardner|first=Lyn|date=2014-08-09|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=2017-02-22|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} Other audience members complained about the noise she was making as a result of her vocal tics and the venue's staff asked her to move into a sound booth, so she wouldn't be heard by other customers. Although initially the experience made her vow never to go to the theatre again, it eventually became the catalyst for her becoming a performer: "The creative way to respond was to occupy that space as an artist".{{Citation|last=British Council Arts|title=Jess Thom on accessibility and Dublin Theatre Festival 2016 (audio described)|date=2017-01-25|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hHKQJ_V2lLs|accessdate=2017-02-22}} Thom is also a wheelchair user. Following the [[social model of disability]], Thom sees most of the challenges she faces not as a result of her unique neurology and physical impairment, but as a result of the 'disabling barriers' created by society, telling BBC News in 2014: "My wheelchair and my tics are not the thing that disables me; the thing that disables me is the inaccessible environment".{{Citation|last=BBC News|title=What is freedom? Jess Thom, 'Touretteshero' - BBC News|date=2014-03-03|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Rqft1YfDDk|accessdate=2017-02-22}} Thom studied at the [[Royal College of Art]], London, graduating in 2005.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-modern/performance-and-music/jess-thom-touretteshero|title=Jess Thom: Touretteshero - Performance at Tate Modern {{!}} Tate|last=Tate|website=Tate|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-02-23}} == Career == === Early career === Prior to becoming a theatre-maker and performer, Thom's career began as a playworker, working with children and young people. She has also been a fundraiser and project coordinator at a charity based in south London. === Touretteshero === In 2010, Thom and longstanding friend and collaborator Matthew Pountney co-founded Touretteshero.{{Cite news|url=https://www.touretteshero.com/about/|title=About Touretteshero|newspaper=Touretteshero|access-date=2017-02-22|language=en-GB}} The idea started out as a way of engaging people with the creative and humorous side of Tourette's, with Thom dressing up in a superhero costume and delivering performances and workshops, especially to children and young people. In 2011, Thom appeared on Episode 3, 'Uses and Abuses' of [[Stephen Fry]]'s five-part BBC series [[Fry's Planet Word]], to discuss her Tourette's and [[coprolalia]] - the involuntary use of swear words which 10% of people with Tourette's experience.{{Citation|last=Touretteshero|title=Fry's Planet Word - Touretteshero|date=2011-10-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vOwPaBDFDi4|accessdate=2017-02-22}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01614w9|title=Uses and Abuses, Fry's Planet Word - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2017-02-22}} The following year, Souvenir Press published ''Welcome to Biscuit Land: A year in the life of Touretteshero'' based on entries on Thom's blog, for which Fry wrote the foreword.{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Welcome-Biscuit-Land-year-Touretteshero-ebook/dp/B009K19DL2/ref=sr_1_2?s=digital-text&ie=UTF8&qid=1487761070&sr=1-2|title=Welcome to Biscuit Land: A year in the life of Touretteshero|last=Thom|first=Jessica|last2=Fry|first2=Mrs Stephen|date=2012-09-29|publisher=Souvenir Press|language=English}} Touretteshero has also put on creative events, like 'We Forgot The Lot!' - a collaboration with [[Tate]] for children and young people with and without Tourette's.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-britain/special-event/we-forgot-lot|title=We forgot the lot! - Special Event at Tate Britain {{!}} Tate|last=Tate|website=Tate|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-02-28}} === Backstage in Biscuit Land === Partly inspired by her negative experience of attending the Mark Thomas gig, and taking its name from Thom's most common vocal tic 'biscuit', ''Backstage in Biscuit Land'' began development as a theatre piece which explores the creative opportunities of Thom's tics and also other people's reaction to them. In 2013, Thom met performer and puppeteer, Jess Mabel Jones at a performance of ''Beauty and the Beast'' by ONEOFUS ([[Mat Fraser]] and [[Julie Atlas Muz]]) in London. Mabel Jones would later become a lead collaborator on ''Backstage in Biscuit Land''. Mabel Jones's role in this 'one-woman show for two' is to make sure Thom doesn't stray too far off topic. Due to Thom's unique and sporadic ticcing, which is riffed on heavily in the show, no two performances are quite the same. The set for the show features 50 items that were the subjects of some of Thom's spontaneous vocal tics during the development cycle, including a 'babygrow for Les Dennis' and 'ducks dressed as pterodactyls'. ''Backstage in Biscuit Land'' received R&D funding from commissioning body Unlimited,{{Cite news|url=http://weareunlimited.org.uk/commission/touretteshero/|title=Touretteshero - Unlimited|newspaper=Unlimited|access-date=2017-02-22|language=en-US}} but crowdfunding was sought to help bring the show to Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Reviews of the initial run at Edinburgh were very positive. Lyn Gardiner in ''The Guardian'' said: "Jess Thom's condition lends her show an absurdist edge Samuel Beckett would be proud of...Tourette's and theatre make a joyous combo". She also described it as "extraordinarily entertaining" awarding it four stars. Alice Jones in ''The Independent'' said: "The humour is black but it's also daft and uplifting, and in places, impossibly moving".{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/edinburgh-festival/backstage-in-biscuit-land-pleasance-courtyard-review-remarkable-tourettes-inspired-comedy-9651503.html|title=Backstage in Biscuit Land, Pleasance Courtyard, review: Remarkable|date=2014-08-06|newspaper=The Independent|access-date=2017-02-22|language=en-GB}} TV Bomb, were perhaps most effusive with their praise declaring: "There are more ideas and imagination in this one hour show than most of the Fringe programme combined," awarding it 5 out of 5.{{Cite news|url=http://www.tvbomb.co.uk/review/backstage-in-biscuit-land/|title=Review: Backstage in Biscuit Land: Pleasance Courtyard: Edinburgh: 5 Bombs|newspaper=TV Bomb {{!}} Reviews and Opinion|access-date=2017-02-22|language=en-GB}} Following its success at Edinburgh, ''Backstage in Biscuit Land'' went on a tour across the UK throughout 2015 and 2016 including a notable performance at the [[Barbican Centre|Barbican]], London. It continued to pick up glowing reviews with ''The Stage'' awarding it four stars and calling the show "a properly joyous thing, funny, informative, and eloquent about the need for theatre to be more accessible to everyone.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2015/backstage-biscuit-land-review-barbican-pit-celebratory-show/|title=Backstage in Biscuit Land review at Barbican Pit – 'a celebratory show' {{!}} Review {{!}} Theatre {{!}} The Stage|newspaper=The Stage|access-date=2017-02-22|language=en-US}} Broadway Baby also awarded the show 4 stars "This show is one big tasty biscuit all right".{{Cite web|url=https://broadwaybaby.com/shows/backstage-in-biscuit-land/706927|title=Backstage in Biscuit Land|website=Broadway Baby|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-02-22}} Later in 2016 the production went international with a tour of North America which included performances at New York's BRIC, Toronto's Harbourfront, San Francisco's International Arts Festival and Los Angeles' Skirball Cultural Center. Performances in Australia included at the Sydney Opera House,{{Cite web|url=https://www.sydneyoperahouse.com/whatson/kath17-backstage-in-biscuit-land.aspx|title=BACKSTAGE IN BISCUIT LAND|website=Sydney Opera House|language=en|access-date=2017-02-22}} Queensland Performing Arts Centre, Brisbane and Melbourne International Festival. The performance at the latter earned the show 4 stars in the Australian edition of ''The Guardian,'' with Steph Harmon describing at as "unpredictable, joyous, must-watch theatre". === Media appearances === Thom appeared on ITV's ''[[This Morning (TV programme)|This Morning]]'' in May 2012 and was interviewed at length by [[Phillip Schofield]] and [[Holly Willoughby]].{{Citation|last=mjp221972|title=Jess Thom Tourettes Hero Interview This Morning 2012|date=2012-05-09|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wyav2KHZP_g|accessdate=2017-02-23}} In March 2013, Thom appeared on RTE's Saturday Night Show with [[Brendan O'Connor (media personality)|Brendan O'Connor]]. In September of that year, Thom delivered a talk about the misconceptions of Tourette's Syndrome at TEDxAlbertopolis, the first [[TED (conference)|TED]] event to take place at London's [[Royal Albert Hall]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.ted.com/tedx/events/7663|title=TEDxAlbertopolis {{!}} TED.com|website=www.ted.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-23}} Following her appearance on Fry's Planet Word in 2014, Thom appeared on Radio 4's [[Today (BBC Radio 4)|The Today Programme]], discussing Tourette's and [[BBC News]] discussing her ideas about 'freedom' later that year.{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9714000/9714435.stm|title=BBC News - Today - My Tourette's tics are really funny|website=news.bbc.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-22}} In October 2015, Thom was interviewed on BBC's ''[[Russell Howard's Good News|Russel Howard's Good News]],'' with the broadcast apparently reaching some 3 million people.{{Cite news|url=http://disabilityarts.online/magazine/opinion/jess-thom-on-taking-biscuit-land-to-the-small-screen/|title=Jess Thom on taking Biscuit Land to the small screen - Disability Arts Online|newspaper=Disability Arts Online|access-date=2017-02-23|language=en-US}} The next month a version of ''Backstage in Biscuit Land'', adapted for television entitled ''Broadcast from Biscuit Land'' had a 30-minute slot on BBC4's Live from Television Centre, the first live broadcast from Television Centre since the building was decommissioned in 2013.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2015/tvc-theatre|title=BBC - BBC announces return to Television Centre for live theatre broadcast - Media Centre|website=www.bbc.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-02-23}} In 2016, Thom appeared on series 10 of Richard Herring's Leicester Square Theatre Podcast.https://www.comedy.co.uk/podcasts/richard_herring_lst_podcast/ == Awards == Touretteshero won the 2014 Total Theatre Award, Best Emerging Company for ''Backstage in Biscuit Land''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.edfringe.com/media/news/total-theatre-award-winners-announced|title=Total Theatre Award winners announced {{!}} Edinburgh Festival Fringe|website=www.edfringe.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-23}} == Disability Activism == Thom is an outspoken advocate of disabled people's rights. Her personal outlook often inverts the typical negative stereotypes associated with disability, for instance she sees her Tourette's as a source of creativity and her wheelchair as a symbol of freedom. She advocates for empowerment of disabled people via the social model of disability, telling Exeunt:
As a society there are still lots of people who think about disability solely in negative terms. The medical model – 'disabled people are broken and need to be fixed' – and the charity model – 'tragic and in need of help' – are ways of conceptualizing disability that remain widespread even though the social model of disability – 'people are disabled by a failure to consider difference' – underpins our legislation and public services.
Following her own negative experiences of attending the theatre, Thom has campaigned to get more 'relaxed performances' (a performance where the audience are allowed to make noise and move around, which is more suitable for certain neurodiverse people) in theatres, as well as making every performance of ''Backstage in Biscuit Land'' a relaxed performance.{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-relaxed-performance-20160530-snap-story.html|title=The theater world is opening its arms to people with Tourette's and autism|last=Greiving|first=Tim|website=latimes.com|access-date=2017-02-23}} Thom has also been an outspoken critic of the [[Government of the United Kingdom|UK Government]]'s cuts to provision for disabled people, telling Disability Arts Online:
So many of the structures that were in place to support disabled people to live independent lives have been dismantled in recent years. Ambitions are being capped because of the structures designed to disable and limit what we have access to. There is a big difference between having basic needs met and having the right to an independent life. With the abolition of the Independent Living Fund and Access to Work and all the other attacks on disabled peoples' rights our only option is to keep fighting.

[[File:Johann Wilhelm Loebell Schuetter.jpg|thumb|Johann Wilhelm Löbell, 1845]] '''Johann Wilhelm Löbell''' (15 September 1786 – 12 July 1863) was a German [[historian]].
==Biography== Löbell was a native of [[Berlin]]. He studied at the Universities of [[University of Heidelberg|Heidelberg]] and [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Berlin]] under [[Friedrich August Wolf|Wolf]] and [[Philipp August Böckh|Böckh]]. He had entered the scholarly life against the wishes of his mother who wanted him to go into business.<ref name=adb>{{Cite ADB|19|35|38|Löbell, Johann Wilhelm|Franz Xaver von Wegele|ADB:Loebell, Johann Wilhelm}}</ref> During the [[War of the Sixth Coalition]] (1812–14), he served as a volunteer in a ''[[Landwehr]]'' installation. He was not on the frontlines but worked in a supporting office.<ref name=adb/>
In 1814 he moved to [[Breslau]], where he soon found work as a teacher in a war college. There he published a historical paper and another one on building connections between the sciences and humanities in gymnasium studies. In 1823, he went to work in Berlin at a military academy as a history teacher.<ref name="adb"/> There he also became involved with the issuance of new editions of [[Karl Friedrich Becker]]'s "''Weltgeschichte''" (World history). He eventually oversaw the issuance of three new editions. During this time period he was friends to [[Henrich Steffens]] (1773-1845) and [[Friedrich von Raumer]] (1781-1873).
In 1829 he became an associate professor of history at the [[University of Bonn]], where two years later he became a full professor. Among the works he wrote at Bonn were "''Gregor von Tours und seine Zeit''" ([[Gregory of Tours]] and his times, 1839), a revision of Becker's "''Weltgeschichte''" (1836–38), "''Weltgeschichte in Umrissen und Ausführungen''" (World history outlined and explained Part I, 1846), "''Die Entwicklung der deutschen Poesie von Klopstocks erstem Auftreten bis zu Goethes Tode''" (The development of German poetry from [[Klopstock]] until [[Goethe]]'s death, 1856–65), and "''Historische Briefe''" (Letters on history, 1861), an anonymous attack on [[Ultramontanism]].
==Legacy== Löbell's large personal library is now kept in a school library at the Bielefeld ''Ratsgymnasium'', and is property of the city of [[Bielefeld]].

[[Cold War]] | awards = [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] | laterwork = [[Company director]], television presenter, author and [[Chancellor (education)|university chancellor]] }} '''Sir John Harvey-Jones''' [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (16 April 1924 – 9 January 2008) was an English businessman. He was the chairman of [[Imperial Chemical Industries]] from 1982 to 1987. He was best known by the public for his [[BBC television]] show, ''Troubleshooter'', in which he advised struggling businesses. ==Early life== John Henry Harvey-JonesGeoffrey Owen, 'Jones, Sir John Henry Harvey- (1924–2008)', ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, Jan 2012 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/99963, accessed 11 Feb 2012] was born in [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], London, but spent most of his early childhood in [[Dhar]], [[India]], where his father was a guardian to a teenage [[maharajah]]. He was shipped back to Britain at age six to attend a [[Preparatory school (UK)|prep school]] at [[Deal, Kent|Deal]], [[Kent]]. He entered [[Britannia Royal Naval College|Dartmouth Royal Naval College]] at age 13. ==Royal Navy career== Harvey-Jones joined Dartmouth Royal Naval College as a cadet in 1937, and in 1940, at the age of 16, he joined [[HMS Diomede (D92)|HMS ''Diomede'']] as a midshipman. The next two ships that he served with, [[HMS Ithuriel (H05)|HMS ''Ithuriel'']] and [[HMS Quentin (G78)|HMS ''Quentin'']], were sunk by enemy action. Harvey-Jones went on to join the [[Royal Navy Submarine Service|submarine service]] in 1942, and received his first command at age 24. With the end of [[World War II]], Harvey-Jones went to the [[University of Cambridge]] to learn [[Russian language|Russian]] in six months and joined [[Naval Intelligence Division|Naval Intelligence]] as an [[Interpreting|interpreter]]. He married Mary Bignell in 1947,{{cite web|url=http://icwales.icnetwork.co.uk/business-in-wales/business-news/2008/01/12/from-bullying-to-the-top-of-industry-91466-20342758/ |title=From bullying to the top of industry |publisher=icWales |date=12 January 2008 |accessdate=15 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118035703/http://icwales.icnetwork.co.uk/business-in-wales/business-news/2008/01/12/from-bullying-to-the-top-of-industry-91466-20342758/ |archivedate=18 January 2008 |df= }} and he commanded the Russian intelligence section under the guise of the "[[British Baltic Fishery Protection Service]]", which used two ex-German [[E-boat]]s for gathering clandestine intelligence on the [[Soviet Baltic Fleet]]. Rising to the rank of [[lieutenant-commander]], Harvey-Jones was awarded a military [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|MBE]] in 1952 for his work in Naval Intelligence, although his citation stated that the award was for "fishery protection duties in the Baltic".{{cite book |last=Elliott and Shukman |first= Geoffrey and Harold |title= Secret Classrooms: An Untold Story of the Cold War |year= 2002|publisher= Samovar|isbn=1-903608-13-9 |page=23}} ==Commercial career== ===Imperial Chemical Industries=== Refused permission by the [[Royal Navy]] to spend more time with his wife and daughter Gaby, who had contracted [[Poliomyelitis|polio]], he resigned his commission in 1956 and joined [[Imperial Chemical Industries]] (ICI) on [[Teesside]] as a junior training manager. In 1973, at age 49, he was promoted to sit on the main board of directors. In April 1982, he became chairman of ICI, only the second split-career man and non-chemist to reach the top. Mentored in part by [[John Adair (Leadership Guru)|John Adair]],[http://www.leadership-studies.com/research/viewabs.asp?id=68 University of Exeter (website accessed 22 March 2007)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416145940/http://www.leadership-studies.com/research/viewabs.asp?id=68 |date=16 April 2007 }} Harvey-Jones saw his responsibilities to both [[stockholder]]s and employees as "making a profit out of the markets where the market is". He maintained a firm belief in "speed rather than direction", on the assumption that "once travelling a company can veer and [[tack (sailing)|tack]] towards the ultimate objective." Thus, at the business level he cut non-profit making and what he saw as non-core businesses, so that at board level he could concentrate on putting more power in fewer hands "to reduce the number of those who can say 'no' and increase the motivation of those who can say 'yes'", maintaining that "there are no bad troops, only bad leaders". After only 30 months in the job, having cut the UK workforce by one third, he had doubled the price of ICI shares and turned a loss into a one billion pound profit. ===Media career=== According to one newspaper, it was the [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]]'s ''[[Troubleshooter (TV series)|Troubleshooter]]'' series, first broadcast in 1990, that made Harvey-Jones the most famous industrialist since [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6285160.stm|title=Obituary: Sir John Harvey-Jones|publisher=BBC News|date=11 January 2008|accessdate=18 October 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/business/manufacturing/former-city-lawyer-digby-jones-6939901|title=Former city lawyer Digby Jones debuts as BBC's Troubleshooter|publisher=Birmingham Post|author=Roz Laws|date=10 April 2014|accessdate=18 October 2015}} It ran to five series and several specials in the 1990s and also won him a [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] award. His advice was at times controversial – in particular he was critical of the [[Morgan Motor Company]], which some argue was vindicated, as it is still trading successfully today. ===Other positions=== In 1989, he became chairman of ''[[The Economist]]'',{{cite news | title = Obituary: John Harvey-Jones | work = The Economist | date = 19 January 2008 | page = 94}} was a non-executive director of [[Grand Metropolitan]] plc (now part of [[Diageo]]), and honorary vice-president of the Institute of Marketing. Harvey-Jones was also chairman of the Burns-Anderson Group plc, a conglomerate spanning merchant banking, financial services, recruitment, marketing and business services, and stockbroking. Between 1986 and 1991, Harvey-Jones served as the second [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] of the [[University of Bradford]]. A commemorative painting exists in the University of Bradford collection,[https://archive.is/20120723104605/http://www.cornucopia.org.uk/html/search/verb/GetRecord/8716 University of Bradford portraits at Cornucopia] and Harvey-Jones also agreed to sit for sculptor [[Jon Edgar]] for a terracotta portrait at Clyro in July 2004.[http://www.jonedgar.co.uk/artwork/harvey-jones/ Picture of bust at Jon Edgar web site] He was chairman of the [[Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust]] and member of the Advisory Council of the [[Prince's Trust]]. In 2001, he became the president of the [[Multiple Sclerosis Trust|MS Trust]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mstrust.org.uk/information/opendoor/articles/0802_03.jsp|title=Sir John Harvey-Jones 1924–2008 |publisher=[[Multiple Sclerosis Trust|MS Trust]]|date=February 2008|accessdate=15 January 2009}} ==Personal life== Described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as one of the best-known British advocates of [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]], Harvey-Jones said, "I don't make a drama out of a crisis. If I gave it up now, my wife would leave me."{{cite web|last=Honigsbaum|first=Mark|title=All you need is love and peace|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/aug/15/health.healthandwellbeing|work=The Guardian|accessdate=13 February 2014}} Having lived most of his post-retirement period in [[Ross-on-Wye]], he died in his sleep after a long illness, aged 83, at the [[Hereford County Hospital]]. ==Awards== *In 1952 he was awarded a military [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|MBE]] for his work in Naval Intelligence. *In 1985 he was voted Britain's most impressive industrialist by company directors interviewed for [[MORI]]'s annual "Captains of Industry" survey. *He was knighted for services to industry in 1985. *In 1986, 1987 and 1988, he received the title of "Industrialist of the Year". *In 1992 was awarded the title "Motivator of the Year". *In 1992 he won a BAFTA for his ''Troubleshooter'' series. ==Bibliography== * ''All Together Now'' (1994), [[Heinemann (publisher)|Heinemann]] ({{ISBN|0-7493-1960-7}}) * ''Getting It Together: Memoirs of a trouble shooter'' (1991), |1987|1993|end=div}} | children = 1 }} '''Linda Evangelista''' (born May 10, 1965) is a Canadian model. She is regarded as one of the most accomplished and influential models of all time,{{cite news|last1=Fennell|first1=Tom|title=The Best in the World|work=Maclean's|date=December 9, 1991|volume=104|page=36(5)}} and has been featured on over 700 magazine covers. Evangelista is primarily known for being the longtime [[muse]] of photographer [[Steven Meisel]],{{cite journal|last1=Gross|first1=Michael|title=Madonna's Magician|journal=New York Magazine|date=October 12, 1992|page=30|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oOQCAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA30|accessdate=April 25, 2016|publisher=New York Media, LLC|issn=0028-7369}}{{cite news|last1=La Ferla|first1=Ruth|title=Fashion; Hot Shot|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/magazine/fashion-hot-shot.html|accessdate=April 14, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=July 7, 1991}} as well as for coining the phrase "We don't wake up for less than $10,000 a day." She holds the record for her multiple appearances on the cover of ''[[Vogue Italia]]'', all of which were photographed by Meisel. Evangelista's modeling career began in 1984 when she signed with [[Elite Model Management]] after having moved from her native Canada to New York City. Upon the suggestion of photographer [[Peter Lindbergh]], Evangelista had her hair cut short in 1988. The haircut, nicknamed "The Linda", not only sparked many copies worldwide, but it also benefited Evangelista's career and helped usher in the era of the supermodel. Described as the "chameleon" of the fashion industry,{{cite news|last1=Rothstein|first1=Mervyn|title=Evangelista!|url=http://www.cigaraficionado.com/webfeatures/show/id/Evangelista_7670|accessdate=May 19, 2015|work=Cigar Aficionado|date=Autumn 1995}} and as a key figure among the five supermodels, Evangelista was one of the most famous women in the world during the late 1980s and throughout the 1990s.{{cite news|last1=Helmore|first1=Edward|title=The Fashionable One; in the Supermodel Era, Linda Evangelista Was the Fashion World's Favourite, and She Can Still Turn It on If the Cause Is Right. but What Gets Her out of Bed Now, Asks Edward Helmore|url=https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1G1-136572361/the-fashionable-one-in-the-supermodel-era-linda#/|accessdate=April 29, 2015|work=The Evening Standard|date=September 23, 2005}} Unlike her colleagues, she chose not to diversify into other ventures outside of modeling. She retired from her career in 1998 and made a comeback three years later, this time working only sporadically. Her achievements as a model led to her being voted as "The Greatest Supermodel of All Time" by the viewers of the television show ''[[Fashion File]]'' in 2008. == Early life == Evangelista was born on May 10, 1965 to Italian parents who had emigrated to Canada.{{cite journal|last1=Van Meter|first1=Jonathan|title=She's Back|journal=Vogue|date=September 2001|pages=572–595}}{{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Jane|title=Linda Evangelista: 'What I really feel about ageing'|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-2752275/Linda-Evangelista-What-I-really-feel-ageing.html|work=Daily Mail|date=September 13, 2014|accessdate=November 26, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Craven|first1=Jo|title=Linda Evangelista biography|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/spy/biographies/linda-evangelista-biography|work=Vogue UK|date=May 11, 2011|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} As the second of three children, Evangelista grew up in a working-class, [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] household in the city of her birth, [[St. Catharines]], [[Ontario]],{{cite news|last1=Beech|first1=Monique|title=New mammography machine offers doctors clearer image|url=http://www.stcatharinesstandard.ca/2009/12/18/new-mammography-machine-offers-doctors-clearer-image|accessdate=April 24, 2015|work=St. Catharines Standard|date=December 18, 2009}}{{cite book|last1=Gross|first1=Michael|title=Model: the ugly business of beautiful women|date=1995|publisher=William Morrow and Company, Inc.|location=New York, NY|isbn=0-688-12659-6|pages=426–435}} where she attended [[Denis Morris Catholic High School]].{{cite news|last1=Fraser|first1=Don|title=Remember Me? Linda Evangelista|url=http://www.thewhig.com/2013/12/03/remember-me-linda-evangelista|work=The Kingston Whig-Standard|date=December 5, 2013|accessdate=June 19, 2014}} Her father, Tomaso, worked for [[General Motors]], and died on January 17, 2014.{{cite web|title=EVANGELISTA, Tomaso 'Tom' Evangelista Obituary|url=http://www.canadianobituaries.com/tomaso-tom-evangelista-obituary-january-17-2014.html|website=Canadian Obituaries|accessdate=June 19, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714191301/http://www.canadianobituaries.com/tomaso-tom-evangelista-obituary-january-17-2014.html|archivedate=July 14, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Her mother, Marisa, was a bookkeeper. Evangelista attended a self-improvement course in a modeling school at the age of 12,{{cite news|last1=Larkworthy|first1=Jane|title=Linda Evangelista on The One Beauty Product She Can't Get Enough Of|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/linda-evangelista-on-the-one-beauty-product-she-cant-get-enough-of|accessdate=October 26, 2017|work=W Magazine|date=November 22, 2016}} where she was taught things such as poise and etiquette,{{cite book|last1=Derrick|first1=Robin|last2=Muir|first2=Robin|title=Vogue Model: The Faces of Fashion|date=2010|publisher=Little, Brown|location=London|isbn=1408702533|page=176}}{{cite web|title=Linda Evangelista - Voguepedia|url=http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Linda_Evangelista|website=Vogue.com|accessdate=May 25, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140806181129/http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Linda_Evangelista|archivedate=August 6, 2014}} and she was advised to attend a modeling course. As a teenager, Evangelista started modeling locally in her hometown.{{cite web|last1=Choi|first1=Mary H.K.|title=House Of Style: Episode 24|url=http://style.mtv.com/house-of-style/collection/20120724/house-of-style-episode-24/|website=MTV.com|date=July 24, 2012|accessdate=June 13, 2014}} In 1981, she took part in the Miss Teen Niagara beauty pageant. And while she did not win the pageant, her presence caught the eye of a representative from [[Elite Model Management]]. At the age of 16, she flew to Japan to model there, but an unpleasant experience involving nudity during a modeling assignment made her want to stop modeling altogether. She returned home to Canada, and two years went by before she decided to try her hand again at modeling.{{cite web|title=Linda Evangelista|url=http://www.biography.com/people/linda-evangelista-20874475#awesm=~oGUGhHqBmUJWvx|website=Biography|accessdate=June 13, 2014|date=2014}} == Career == === 1984–1987: Beginnings and success === Evangelista moved to New York City in 1984 upon signing with Elite, where she met the prominent modeling agent [[John Casablancas]], who compared her likeness to the model [[Joan Severance]].{{cite news|title=Linda Evangelista|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/fashion/linda-evangelista/|work=Interview Magazine| date= September 2013|accessdate= June 13, 2014}} Elite then moved Evangelista to Paris, where she launched her international high-fashion career at the age of 19. Her first major fashion magazine cover was for the November 1984 issue of ''[[L'Officiel]]''. Subsequently, she would go on to appear on the covers and in the pages of a variety of international publications including ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'', ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'', ''[[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]]'', ''[[Mademoiselle (magazine)|Mademoiselle]]'', ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'', ''[[W (magazine)|W]]'', ''[[Marie Claire]]'', ''[[Allure (magazine)|Allure]]'', ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', ''[[Cigar Aficionado]]'', and ''[[i-D]]''.{{cite news|last1= Sherwood|first1=James|title=Linda Evangelista: This year's model|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/linda-evangelista-this-years-model-567234.html| work=The Independent|date=March 22, 2004|accessdate=June 13, 2014}} All amounting to a total of more than 700 covers worldwide.{{cite news|last1=Earnshaw|first1=Jessica|title=You'll never believe what former supermodel Linda Evangelista looks like now…|url= http://www.express.co.uk/celebrity-news/658764/Linda-Evangelista-looks-like-now-age-career-big-six|accessdate=June 24, 2016|work=Daily Express|date=April 6, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Forrester|first1=Katy|title=Model Linda Evangelista makes rare public appearance after coming out of retirement and looks very different| url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/model-linda-evangelista-makes-rare-7700925|accessdate=June 24, 2016|work=The Daily Mirror| date=April 6, 2016}} In 1985, she began working with [[Karl Lagerfeld]],{{cite news|last1=Fishwick|first1= Samuel|title=Dressing up with Linda Evangelista|url= https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/esmagazine/dressing-up-with-linda-evangelista-9841862.html| accessdate= November 26, 2014|work=London Evening Standard| date=November 5, 2014}} the head designer of the fashion house [[Chanel]], to whom she would become a muse. On the subject of Evangelista, Lagerfeld once uttered, "There is not another model in the world as professional as she is."{{cite news|last1=Barns |first1=Sarah |last2=Hill |first2=Bethan |title=The New Supermodels |url=http://forgetoday.com/lifestyle/the-new-supermodels/ |work=Forge Today |date=November 21, 2008 |accessdate=June 13, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714222556/http://forgetoday.com/lifestyle/the-new-supermodels/ |archivedate=July 14, 2014 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Linda Evangelista|url= http://www.canadaswalkoffame.com/inductees/2003/linda-evangelista|website=Canada's Walk Of Fame|accessdate=April 29, 2015}} Incidentally, Evangelista became one of the first editorial models to successfully cross over into the realm of runway modeling. She also became a muse to the late fashion designer [[Gianni Versace]],{{cite web|last1= Fidanzia|first1= Valentina|title=Linda Evangelista|url=http://www.vogue.it/en/encyclo/people/e/linda-evangelista|website= Vogue Italia|accessdate= June 19, 2014}} for whom she first appeared in ad campaigns in 1987. In addition to her work for Versace and Lagerfeld, Evangelista also modeled for various other fashion brands such as [[Valentino SpA|Valentino]], [[Dolce & Gabbana]], [[Gianfranco Ferré]], [[Ralph Lauren Corporation|Ralph Lauren]], [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Yves Saint Laurent]], [[Azzedine Alaïa]], [[Oscar de la Renta]], [[Giorgio Armani S.p.A.|Giorgio Armani]], [[Thierry Mugler]], [[Claude Montana]], [[Donna Karan International|Donna Karan]], [[Jil Sander (brand)|Jil Sander]], [[Jean Paul Gaultier]], [[Alberta Ferretti]], [[Isaac Mizrahi]], [[Escada]], [[Calvin Klein]], [[Salvatore Ferragamo S.p.A.|Salvatore Ferragamo]], [[MaxMara|Max Mara]], [[Perry Ellis (brand)|Perry Ellis]], [[Chloé]], [[Comme des Garçons]], [[Bill Blass Limited|Bill Blass]], and [[Herve Leger]].{{cite web|last1=Dishman|first1=Lydia|title=It's Going to Take More than Linda Evangelista to Make Over Talbots|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/its-going-to-take-more-than-linda-evangelista-to-make-over-talbots/|website= CBSNews.com|accessdate=June 9, 2016|date=June 10, 2010}} And, she has represented a diverse array of other companies and non-fashion brands like [[Visa Inc.|Visa]], [[American Express]], [[Pizza Hut]], [[De Beers]], and [[Elizabeth Arden, Inc.|Elizabeth Arden]].{{cite news|last1=Kuczynski|first1=Alex|title=Trading on Hollywood Magic; Celebrities Push Models Off Women's Magazine Covers| url= https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/30/business/trading-on-hollywood-magic-celebrities-push-models-off-women-s-magazine-covers.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=April 25, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=January 30, 1999}}{{cite web|title=Linda Evangelista|url=http://nymag.com/fashion/models/levangelista/lindaevangelista/|website=New York Magazine|accessdate=June 13, 2014}}{{cite book|last=Gunter|first=Barrie|title=Celebrity Capital: Assessing the Value of Fame|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IzxeBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA82| date= September 25, 2014|publisher= Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn= 978-1-62892-332-2|page= 82}}{{cite news|last1=Sherwood|first1=James|title=interview linda evangelista; I will survive|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/interview-linda-evangelista-i-will-survive-1252761.html|accessdate=June 9, 2016|work=The Independent |date=July 26, 1997}}{{cite news|last1= Snead|first1= Elizabeth |title=Crystallizing opinion|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/oct/10/entertainment/et-diamonds10|accessdate= June 9, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=October 10, 2006}}{{cite news|last1=Elliott|first1=Stuart|title=THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Miscellany|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/03/business/the-media-business-advertising-addenda-miscellany.html|accessdate= April 25, 2016|work=The New York Times|date= January 3, 1996}} In 1986, Evangelista met the photographer [[Steven Meisel]],{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1=Conor|title=Sex, Drugs, Cameras|url=http://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/cgi-bin/columbia?a=d&d=cs19950413-01.2.42&srpos=1&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN-ARTICLE----#|accessdate= November 26, 2014|work=Columbia Daily Spectator|issue=54|date=April 13, 1995|page=13}} with whom she forged a friendship.{{cite book| first =Roshumba | last = Williams|title=The Complete Idiot's Guide to Being a Model|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=VzrZqkiF2yYC&pg=PA226|year=1999|publisher= Alpha Books|isbn= 978-0-02-863190-5| page= 226}} From that point on, they began working together on many professional collaborations, and Evangelista became Meisel's muse in the process.{{cite news|last1=Cerf De Dudzeele|first1=Carlyne|title=Heroes: Linda Evangelista|url= http://vmagazine.com/site/content/1414/heroes-linda-evangelista|accessdate= June 24, 2016|work=V Magazine|issue=V85|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140410172829/http://vmagazine.com/site/content/1414/heroes-linda-evangelista|archivedate=April 10, 2014}} Starting in 1987, Evangelista began to appear in advertisements and commercials for [[Revlon]]'s "The Most Unforgettable Women in the World" campaign,{{cite web|title= Revlon - Voguepedia|url=http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Revlon|website= Vogue.com|accessdate=May 25, 2015|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20140228055611/http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Revlon|archivedate=February 28, 2014}} which was photographed by [[Richard Avedon]]. She has also been photographed by the likes of [[Peter Lindbergh]], [[Irving Penn]], [[Francesco Scavullo]], [[Herb Ritts]], [[Bruce Weber (photographer)|Bruce Weber]], [[Gian Paolo Barbieri]], [[Patrick Demarchelier]], [[Paolo Roversi]], [[Norman Parkinson]], [[Arthur Elgort]], [[Gilles Bensimon]], [[Ellen von Unwerth]], [[Sante D'Orazio]], and [[Nick Knight (photographer)|Nick Knight]] among others. === 1988–1992: The supermodel era === It was Lindbergh who, in the fall of 1988, suggested to Evangelista that she cut her hair short{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Laura|title=Classic Lindbergh|url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/fashion-articles/classic-lindbergh-0409|work=Harper's Bazaar| date=March 23, 2009|accessdate= June 13, 2014}} after seeing her try on a short wig for a photoshoot. Consequently, she got a short [[gamine]] haircut from the French hairstylist Julien d'Ys.{{cite news|title=Long And Short Are Equally In|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1990-06-15/lifestyle/9006140701_1_coif-fashion-today-long-and-short|work= [[Orlando Sentinel]] |date=June 15, 1990|accessdate=June 13, 2014}} The following day, she was photographed by Lindbergh, which resulted in a now-famous photograph known as "the white shirt picture". Initially, the haircut was not well received by the fashion industry, and Evangelista was cancelled from 16 fashion shows.{{cite web|last1=Peltz|first1=Jennifer|title=Evangelista testifies at NY child-support trial|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2012/05/04/evangelista-testifies-at-ny-child-support-trial/|website= FOXNews.com|date=May 4, 2012|accessdate= June 13, 2014}} However, by the spring of 1989, Evangelista's haircut was the look of the season.{{cite news|last= Wells| first= Linda| title=BEAUTY/FASHION; WHAT THEY'RE WEARING: Short Hair|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/28/magazine/beauty-fashion-what-they-re-wearing-short-hair.html|accessdate=April 27, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=May 28, 1989}}{{cite news|last =Cook|first= Catherine|title=Hair In Tune With '60s Styles Reminiscent Of Age Of Aquarius Are Back In Fashion|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1990-08-24/lifestyle/9008230016_1_headbands-hair-bright-colors|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=August 24, 1990|accessdate=June 13, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Patteson|first1=Jean|title=Hair For The Holidays| url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-11-27/lifestyle/9211250315_1_styles-hair-waves-dry-hair|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=November 27, 1992|accessdate=June 13, 2014}} The haircut was referred to as "The Linda", and it inspired the creation of a wig called "The Evangelista". Even famous women sought to emulate the look. Among them were [[Demi Moore]], who sported the haircut in the 1990 film ''[[Ghost (1990 film)|Ghost]]'', and [[Susan Sullivan]] from the television show ''[[Falcon Crest]]''. It has been said of Evangelista that "the world's most famous haircut turned her from an averagely in-demand top model to an insanely in-demand, only-Linda-will-do top model, so sensationally successful that the word 'supermodel' had to be coined to describe her".{{cite news|last1=Pielou|first1=Adriaane|title=Viva Linda|url=https://www.questia.com/article/1G1-114494879/viva-linda#/|accessdate= November 26, 2014|work=The Mail on Sunday | place= London |date=March 21, 2004}} Evangelista became known as one of the five supermodels, a group of star models who reached the pinnacle of success during the late 1980s and early 1990s.{{cite news|last1=Skarda|first1=Erin|title=Linda Evangelista - All-TIME Top 100 Icons in Fashion, Style and Design|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2110513_2110628_2110743,00.html|work=Time|date=April 2, 2012|accessdate= June 13, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Bowles|first1=Hamish|title=Agents Provocateurs: A Look at Vogue's New Book The Editor's Eye|url=http://www.vogue.com/magazine/article/excerpt-of-vogue-the-editors-eye-book/#1|work=Vogue|date=August 23, 2012|accessdate=June 19, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131130174937/http://www.vogue.com/magazine/article/excerpt-of-vogue-the-editors-eye-book/#1|archivedate=November 30, 2013|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|last= Ghorbani|first= Liza|title= Christy Turlington: A Model Mom|url= http://dujour.com/gallery/christy-turlington-a-model-mom/35710|work=DuJour|date=Fall 2012|accessdate=June 13, 2014}} The supermodels were considered more famous than most actresses and singers of that time.{{cite news|last1=Campbell|first1=Roy H.|title=Fashion's Final 4: The Megamodels These Runway Stars Are Megafamous - And They Are Known To Make Megabucks.|url=http://articles.philly.com/1992-04-05/news/26004887_1_ethnic-model-models-today-top-models|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer Online|date=April 5, 1992|accessdate=June 19, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1= Dana|title=Elle Macpherson invades Hollywood|url=http://www.ew.com/article/1994/03/25/elle-macpherson-invades-hollywood|accessdate=April 14, 2015| work= Entertainment Weekly|date=March 25, 1994}} In addition, Evangelista, along with [[Christy Turlington]] and [[Naomi Campbell]] comprised a triumvirate that was dubbed "The Trinity". They were joined by [[Cindy Crawford]] and [[Tatjana Patitz]] for the cover of the January 1990 issue of ''[[British Vogue]]'', which was photographed by Lindbergh. The cover itself was said to have "defined the supermodel era".{{cite news|title=A centenary of style|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20160320/travel/A-centenary-of-style.606321|accessdate=June 28, 2016|work=Times of Malta|date=March 20, 2016}} Upon seeing the cover, the singer [[George Michael]] chose to cast these five models{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.georgemichael.com/about/|website=GeorgeMichael.com|accessdate=June 19, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907135045/http://www.georgemichael.com/about/|archivedate=September 7, 2013|df=mdy-all}} in the music video for his song, "[[Freedom! '90]]", in which they lipsynched the words to the song. In May of that year, Evangelista was chosen as one of the "50 Most Beautiful People in the World" by ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''. She also appeared on the ''[[Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' where she served as a judge for an Elite model search competition, and chose [[Leslie Bibb]] as the winner, who later became an actress.{{cite book|title= Mr. Skin's Skincyclopedia: The A-to-Z Guide to Finding Your Favorite Actresses Naked|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=dMMP94fw3mgC&pg=PA64|year=2005|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn= 978-0-312-33144-3| page= 64}} {{Reduced pull quote|right|We have this expression, Christy and I. We don't wake up for less than $10,000 a day.|Evangelista's famous quote from
''Vogue'''s October 1990 issue}} In an interview printed in the October 1990 issue of ''Vogue'', Evangelista said the words, "We don't wake up for less than $10,000 a day."{{cite journal|last1=Van Meter|first1= Jonathan|title=Pretty Women|journal= Vogue|date=October 1990|volume=180|issue=10}} That statement is now thought of as the most famous quote in modeling history,{{cite web| last1=Blakeley|first1=Kiri|title=Rich, Beautiful and on Top of the World|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/FunMoney/story?id=3387021&page=1|website=ABCNews.com|accessdate=June 19, 2014|date=July 18, 2007}} and it has been described as "the '[[Let them eat cake]]' of the 20th century".{{cite news|last1=Cartner-Morley|first1=Jess|title=Vintage model|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2001/aug/16/gender.uk1|accessdate=April 29, 2015|work=The Guardian|date=August 16, 2001}}{{cite journal|last1=Scherer|first1= Debra|title=Jonathan Van Meter and the Age of Celebrity|journal=The Business of Fashion|date=August 21, 2014|url=http://www.businessoffashion.com/2014/08/jonathan-van-meter-age-celebrity.html|accessdate= August 26, 2014}} Also in October 1990, Evangelista stunned the fashion world by having the hairstylist [[Oribe (hairdresser)|Oribe]] dye her naturally-brown hair platinum blond.{{cite news|title= Cutting-Edge Model Linda Evangelista Drops a Blond Bombshell on the Fashion World—Color It Disapproving|url= http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20113678,00.html|work= People|date= November 19, 1990|accessdate= June 13, 2014|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140714173600/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20113678,00.html|archivedate= July 14, 2014|df= mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=Oribe - Voguepedia|url=http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Oribe_Canales|website=Vogue.com|accessdate=May 25, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714212642/http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Oribe_Canales|archivedate=July 14, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Is Blond Hair Worth Dyeing For?|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1991-06-07/lifestyle/9106060562_1_blond-hair-salon|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=June 7, 1991|accessdate=June 13, 2014}} Months later, she had her hair dyed a shocking shade of red known as "[[technicolor]] red".{{cite news|last1= Patteson|first1=Jean|title=The Blessing/curse Of Being A Redhead|url= http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1991-10-11/lifestyle/9110110699_1_red-hair-redhead-hair-bac|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=October 11, 1991|accessdate=June 13, 2014}} Throughout most of her modeling career, Evangelista was referred to as the fashion industry's "chameleon" for the way that she constantly reinvented herself with various hairstyles and ever-changing hair colors that inspired hair trends.{{cite news|title=Roller Sets Can Do Something For Everyone|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1991-10-04/lifestyle/9110030805_1_roller-set-heated-rollers-supermodel-linda-evangelista|work= Orlando Sentinel|date=October 4, 1991|accessdate=June 13, 2014}} In terms of her looks, she was likened to [[Sophia Loren]], [[Elizabeth Taylor]], [[Ava Gardner]], and [[Gina Lollobrigida]]. In 1991, it was rumored that the fashion house [[Lanvin (clothing)|Lanvin]] paid Evangelista $20,000 to walk in their [[haute couture]] show for the spring/summer season, an amount that was considered excessive.{{cite news|last1=Morgan|first1=Pat|title =High price of supermodels is passed on to consumers|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1991-11-13/features/1991317223_1_linda-evangelista-runway-models-cindy-crawford|work=The Baltimore Sun|date=November 13, 1991|accessdate= June 13, 2014}} Male model [[Tyson Beckford]] recounted in an interview that Evangelista was instrumental in getting higher rates for models.{{cite news|last1=Cowles|first1=Charlotte|title=Tyson Beckford Once Got Paid $40,000 a Day|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2012/04/tyson-beckford-linda-evangelista-overpaid.html|work=The Cut (New York Magazine)|accessdate=June 20, 2014|date=April 24, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714201518/http://nymag.com/thecut/2012/04/tyson-beckford-linda-evangelista-overpaid.html|archivedate=July 14, 2014|df=mdy-all}} That April, Evangelista waived her runway fee as an act of support for fashion designer [[Anna Sui]]'s debut collection, and instead accepted clothing as payment.{{cite book|last=Muaddi Darraj|first=Susan|title=Anna Sui|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iBYU7ANQMsgC&pg=PA41|year=2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn= 978-1-4381-2864-1|accessdate=June 20, 2014|page=41}}{{cite web|title= Anna Sui - Voguepedia|url=http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Anna_Sui|website=Vogue.com|accessdate=May 25, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140818002747/http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Anna_Sui|archivedate=August 18, 2014}} Two months later, she attended Valentino's 30th Anniversary Gala in Rome, Italy with Meisel.{{cite journal|last1=Gross|first1=Michael|title=There's No Place Like Rome| journal=New York Magazine|date=June 24, 1991|volume=24|issue=25|pages=11–13|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D-kCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11&dq=evangelista+meisel+valentino+gala+1991+-forum+-wordpress+-blogspot+-pinterest+-tumblr+-facebook+-ebay&source=bl&ots=Bun4TaIven&sig=5mDYWDJ-7BiRycEO97QR-fM9XOg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=tdmjU72pLIWAqgam9IHwDA&ved=0CDcQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=June 20, 2014|issn= 0028-7369}}{{cite news|last1= Morris|first1=Bernadine|title=From Valentino, Three Decades Of Glamour|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/news/from-valentino-three-decades-of-glamour.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=June 20, 2014|date=June 11, 1991}} In September 1991, ''Time'' featured a cover story on the supermodels.{{cite journal|last1= Rudolph|first1=Barbara|title=Supermodels: Beauty and the Bucks|journal=Time |date=Sep 16, 1991|issue= 37|pages=44–50}} The following month, in an article for ''Vogue'', fashion journalist [[Suzy Menkes]] described Evangelista as "the world's star model".{{cite journal|last1=Menkes|first1= Suzy|title=The Couture Controversy|journal= Vogue|date=October 1991}} Evangelista then starred in the 1991 documentary ''Models: The Film'', directed by Lindbergh.{{cite web|title=Peter Lindbergh - Voguepedia|url= http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Peter_Lindbergh| website=Vogue.com|accessdate= May 25, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140331222420/http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Peter_Lindbergh|archivedate=March 31, 2014}} And, an episode of the [[MTV]] show ''[[House of Style]]'' devoted a segment to Evangelista, which was filmed in Paris.{{cite web|last1=Choi|first1=Mary H.K.|title=House Of Style: Episode 12|url=http://style.mtv.com/house-of-style/collection/20120724/house-of-style-episode-12/|website= MTV.com|date= July 24, 2012|accessdate=June 13, 2014}} During the latter part of 1991 and throughout 1992, Evangelista was seen on several different billboards for the fashion brand Kenar, in the center of [[Times Square]].{{cite news|last1=Pace|first1= Eric|title=CHRONICLE| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/style/chronicle-987491.html|accessdate=April 27, 2016| work= The New York Times|date=September 19, 1991}}{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Linda|title=Fashion Ads Get Simple, Yet Profound|url=http://newsok.com/fashion-ads-get-simple-yet-profound/article/2382230|work=NewsOK|accessdate=June 24, 2014|date=January 19, 1992}}{{cite news|last1=Pener|first1=Degen|title=EGOS & IDS; NOTES|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1992/11/08/style/egos-ids-notes.html|accessdate= April 27, 2016| work=The New York Times|date= November 8, 1992}} The billboards were done in conjunction with Ads Against AIDS, which was a campaign created by the advertising industry to raise awareness about tackling the disease.{{cite news|last1=Elliott|first1=Stuart|title=The Media Business: Advertising -- Addenda; AIDS Campaign Gets A Corporate Sponsor|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/30/business/the-media-business-advertising-addenda-aids-campaign-gets-a-corporate-sponsor.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=June 24, 2014|date=August 30, 1991}} The most talked about and most controversial of those billboards was one that showed Evangelista seated among seven older [[Sicily|Sicilian]] women.{{cite news|last1=Cloud|first1=Barbara|title=AIDS billboard sparks Italian protest|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19920109&id=ynUcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dGQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5472,3867702&hl=en|work=The Pittsburgh Press|accessdate=June 24, 2014|date=January 9, 1992}} It was said that the image, which got dubbed "Beauty and the Seven Beasts" by [[Richard Johnson (columnist)|Richard Johnson]] in the ''[[New York Post]]'',{{cite journal|last1= Lockwood|first1=Lisa|title=Controversies and Cappuccino|journal=Women's Wear Daily|date= March 30, 2012|page=18}} promoted a negative depiction of Italian women.{{cite news|last1=Madison|first1=Cathy|title=Sicilian Sues Over Ad Featuring Aids Theme|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-06-28/features/9202260855_1_aids-victim-aids-project-aids-education-group|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=June 24, 2014|date=June 28, 1992}} Nonetheless, limited edition prints of the image were sold for $1,000 a piece, to benefit Ads Against AIDS.{{cite news|last1= Fabrikant|first1=Geraldine|title=The Media Business: Advertising -- Addenda; New Campaigns|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/24/business/the-media-business-advertising-addenda-new-campaigns.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=June 24, 2014|date=December 24, 1991}} Also, the image was chosen as one of the "20 most important fashion photographs ever" by the [[International Center of Photography]].{{cite news|title=Kenneth Zimmerman Obituary|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/nytimes/obituary.aspx?pid=171564405|work=The New York Times|accessdate=July 14, 2014|date= July 1, 2014}} Kenneth Zimmerman, president of Kenar, said of Evangelista, "She has increased our sales dramatically." He further added, "Linda was our [[Michael Jordan]]. We chose her because we wanted a star, and of the four or five star models, she is number one." In April 1992, Evangelista and several other supermodels appeared on the cover of the 100th anniversary issue of ''Vogue'', which remains to this day as the magazine's highest-selling issue.{{cite news|last1=Sowray|first1=Bibby|title=Kim and Kanye's Vogue cover on course to be a record seller|url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/columns/bibby-sowray/TMG10754886/Kim-and-Kanyes-Vogue-cover-on-course-to-be-a-record-seller.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=June 25, 2014|date=April 9, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Essex|first1=Myeisha|title=Vogue's Kim K & Kanye Cover On Track To Outsell FLOTUS & Beyonce Issues|url=http://michronicleonline.com/2014/04/08/vogues-kim-k-kanye-cover-on-track-to-outsell-flotus-beyonce-issues|work= [[The Michigan Chronicle]] |accessdate= June 25, 2014|date=April 8, 2014}} She then appeared in the music video for George Michael's "[[Too Funky]]" song,{{cite web|last1=Borrelli-Persson|first1=Laird|title='Moulin Rouge Meets Vegas!' An Oral History of George Michael’s 1992 “Too Funky” Video|url=http://www.vogue.com/13428238/george-michael-supermodels-linda-evangelista/|website= Vogue.com|accessdate=April 25, 2016|date=April 20, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Van Meter|first1=William|title=Bold Crossings of the Gender Line|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/09/fashion/09TRANS.html|accessdate=April 27, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=December 8, 2010}} in which she parodied her modeling persona. In July 1992, she was on the cover of Canadian fashion magazine ''[[Flare (magazine)|Flare]]'', which was an issue honoring Canada's 125 years as a nation. She was also said to have started the trend for thin eyebrows,{{cite news|last1=Trucco|first1=Terry|title=Beauty; The Big Tweeze|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/09/magazine/beauty-the-big-tweeze.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=June 25, 2014|date=February 9, 1992}}{{cite news|last1=Lytle|first1=Lisa|title=Raising fashion's eyebrows Summer's look is well- defined, arched and, for some, thin|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1992-07-22/features/1992204187_1_thin-eyebrows-arched-eyebrows-well-defined|work=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=June 25, 2014|date=July 22, 1992}} which later coincided with the arrival of the Neo-[[Hippie]] fashion trend in the fall of 1992.{{cite news|last1=Patteson|first1=Jean|title=New Choices: Hippie, Ethnic|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-10-30/lifestyle/9210290734_1_hippie-christian-lacroix-emanuel-ungaro|work=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=June 25, 2014|date= October 30, 1992}} Her cover for the September 1992 issue of ''Harper's Bazaar''{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1= Bob |title=THE NIGHT; Too Elegant For Words|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/09/13/style/the-night-too-elegant-for-words.html|accessdate=April 27, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=September 13, 1992}}{{cite news|last1=Schiro|first1=Anne-Marie|title=Elizabeth Tilberis, 51, Magazine Editor, Dies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/22/arts/elizabeth-tilberis-51-magazine-editor-dies.html|accessdate=April 27, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=April 22, 1999}}{{cite news|last1=Dullea|first1=Georgia|title=Liz Tilberis's Kind of September|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/23/style/liz-tilberis-s-kind-of-september.html|accessdate=April 27, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=August 23, 1992}} is now seen as "iconic", and it was ranked #9 on the [[American Society of Magazine Editors]]' list of the "Top 40 Magazine Covers of the Last 40 Years" in 2005.{{cite web|title=ASME's Top 40 Magazine Covers of the Last 40 Years|url=http://www.magazine.org/asme/magazine-cover-contests/asmes-top-40-magazine-covers-last-40-years|website=American Society of Magazine Editors|accessdate=June 25, 2014}} Toward the end of 1992, her name was immortalized in [[RuPaul]]'s song, "[[Supermodel (You Better Work)]]". === 1993–1998: The latter years === Evangelista made headlines in 1993 when she traveled to Australia with [[Claudia Schiffer]] for a 5-day tour, which included a news conference and a televised fashion show, as part of the grand opening of a department store.{{cite news|last1=Green|first1=Sue|title=Catwalk coup sparks Aussie fashion frenzy|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/42444/catwalk-coup-sparks-aussie-fashion-frenzy|work=South China Morning Post|accessdate=June 26, 2014|date=September 1, 1993}}{{cite news|last1=Gendel|first1=Debra|title=Supermodels Profit Down Under|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-09-10/news/vw-33610_1_net-profits|work=Los Angeles Times|date=September 10, 1993}} In October 1994, Evangelista was one of several models on the cover of ''[[Vogue Italia]]''′s 30th anniversary issue. She then appeared in the feature film ''[[Prêt-à-Porter (film)|Prêt-à-Porter]]''. In 1995, the hairstylist Garren of New York changed Evangelista's look by giving her an asymmetrical bob similar to [[Mod (subculture)|mod]] hairstyles of the 1960s.{{cite news|last1=Boddiford|first1=Suzin|title=Decades-old mod is modern again|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1995-10-12/features/1995285153_1_mod-garren-bangs|work=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=June 26, 2014|date=October 12, 1995}}{{cite news|last1=Spindler|first1=Amy M.|title=Reviews/Fashion; Runway Homages to a Mod Trend Setter|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/08/style/reviews-fashion-runway-homages-to-a-mod-trend-setter.html|accessdate=April 1, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=April 8, 1995}} That same year, she took part in Thierry Mugler's 20th anniversary fashion show.{{cite web|title=Thierry Mugler - Voguepedia|url=http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Thierry_Mugler|website=Vogue.com|accessdate=May 25, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811102211/http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Thierry_Mugler|archivedate=August 11, 2014}} Evangelista later landed an endorsement deal with [[Clairol]] worth over $5 million.{{cite news|title=Clairol deal gives millions to model Linda...|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1995-06-23/news/9506230864_1_linda-evangelista-clairol-ultress|work=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=June 13, 2014|date=June 23, 1995}} She also starred in the fashion documentary ''[[Unzipped (film)|Unzipped]]''. Additionally, she was a presenter at the [[Miss World 1995]] competition. In 1996, Evangelista was one of the ten subjects of Lindbergh's book ''10 Women'', on whose cover she appeared. She was also seen in the fashion documentary ''[[Catwalk (1995 film)|Catwalk]]''. That's my line! Only now it's a half million and it's a man saying it."
