One of the images from that spread is known as "The Wild Ones", and a platinum-palladium print of the image was sold at a [[Sotheby's]] auction for over $30,000.{{cite web|title=THE WILD ONES: CINDY CRAWFORD, TATJANA PATITZ, HELENA CHRISTENSEN, LINDA EVANGELISTA, CLAUDIA SCHIFFER, NAOMI CAMPBELL, KAREN MULDER, STEPHANIE SEYMOUR, VOGUE US, BROOKLYN', 1991|url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2014/photographs-l14780/lot.103.html|website=Sotheby's|accessdate=May 4, 2016|location=London|date=May 7, 2014}} In October 2012, a picture of Evangelista and McMenamy that was photographed by Meisel for ''Vogue'''s October 1992 issue was sold at a [[Phillips (auctioneers)|Phillips]] auction for $86,500.{{cite web|title=Walking in Paris, Linda Evangelista & Kristen McMenamy, Vogue, October, 1992|url=http://www.phillips.com/detail/STEVEN-MEISEL/NY040212/62|website=Phillips|accessdate=May 4, 2016|location=New York|date=October 2, 2012}} In May 2016, a 1988 picture of Evangelista and five other models that was photographed by Lindbergh sold at a Sotheby's auction for $118,462.{{cite journal|last1=Heinzinger|first1=Kristen|title=Sotheby’s Sells Over $2 Million of Fashion Photographers’ Work|journal=Daily Front Row|date=May 19, 2016|url=http://fashionweekdaily.com/sothebys-sells-over-2-million-of-fashion-photographers-work/|accessdate=June 28, 2016}} A 1996 photograph of Evangelista, titled "Linda Kissing Linda", which was originally featured in a Kenar advertisement, was selected by the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum|Guggenheim Museum]] as "an example of the epitome of [[androgyny]]". Even now in the 21st century, Evangelista continues to be an influence to other people. Due to her talent as a model as well as her personal image, Evangelista has been named by a number of female celebrities as either an inspiration or as a beauty icon. Among them are [[Victoria Beckham]], [[Martha Stewart]], models [[Candice Swanepoel]], [[Kylie Bax]], [[Kendall Jenner]] and [[Elsa Benítez]], model-turned-actress [[Angie Harmon]], and singer [[Rihanna]].{{cite journal|title=POSH FRIENDS|journal=British Vogue|date=November 30, 2001|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2001/11/30/posh-friends|accessdate=May 5, 2016}}{{cite journal|last=Kasindorf|first=Jeanie|title=Living With Martha|journal=New York Magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WekCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA28|date=January 28, 1991|publisher=New York Media, LLC|page=28|issn=0028-7369}}{{cite journal|last1=Niven|first1=Lisa|title=Candice Swanepoel: 10 Questions|journal=British Vogue|date=August 18, 2015|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/beauty/2015/08/18/candice-swanepoel-beauty-interview-10-questions|accessdate=May 13, 2016}}{{cite journal|last1=Driver|first1=George|title=Ultimate Angel Candice Swanepoel On Home Made Beauty Smoothies, Laughing Her Way To A Six Pack And Why She Hates Having Her Hair Done|journal=InStyle UK|date=November 13, 2015|url=http://www.instyle.co.uk/beauty/tips/candice-swanepoel-beauty-tips|accessdate=May 13, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Okwodu|first1=Janelle|title=’90s Models: A Look Back at the Faces—Famous and Slightly Less So—That Defined a Decade|url=http://www.vogue.com/13297845/georgina-grenville-yasmeen-ghauri-90s-models-now/|website=Vogue.com|accessdate=May 5, 2016|date=August 31, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=de Paz|first1=Dalia|title=A Tyra Banks le gustaría ver más modelos latinas|trans-title=Tyra Banks would like to see more Latin models|url=http://archivo.eluniversal.com.mx/espectaculos/106100.html|accessdate=May 9, 2016|work=El Universal|date=August 2, 2011|language=Spanish}}{{cite web|last1=Van Meter|first1=Jonathan|title=Rihanna: Living Out Loud|url=http://www.vogue.com/865450/rihanna-living-out-loud/|website=Vogue.com|accessdate=May 5, 2016|date=March 16, 2011}} In the past as well as the present day, Evangelista has drawn praise and accolades from many of the fashion industry's elite. As far as Treacy is concerned, "Linda is the ultimate model of the past 50 years".{{cite news|last1=Power|first1=Bairbre|title=Top Hat... Philip Treacy's two decades of creating masterpieces|url=http://www.independent.ie/style/fashion/top-hat-philip-treacys-two-decades-of-creating-masterpieces-31609729.html|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=Irish Independent|date=October 18, 2015}} Lagerfeld, who had once described Evangelista as "the most famous of all",{{cite news|last1=Tempest|first1=Rone|title=Kaiser Karl : One Minute, He's Revising the Chanel Suit. Next, He's Mixing Up a Grapefruit-Mandarin-Scented Men's Perfume. Then, He's Making and Breaking Top Models. Does Karl Lagerfeld Ever Sit Still?|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-04-14/magazine/tm-535_1_karl-lagerfeld/3|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=April 14, 1991}} said that she is "the best model in the world".{{cite news|last1=Beker|first1=Jeanne|title=What's wrong with staying a model?|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/whats-wrong-with-staying-a-model/article18282158/|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=The Globe and Mail|date=May 15, 2004}} His reasoning is "Because she's a true model, pure and simple. She doesn't pretend or aspire to do anything else. She's just brilliant at what she does." Fellow designer [[Stefano Gabbana]] said of Evangelista, "Linda is ''the'' model. If you talk about models of the sixties and seventies, the first name is [[Veruschka]]. In the eighties and nineties, it's Linda." David Bonnouvrier, one of the founders of DNA Model Management said, "Linda is the model of all time, to its strictest definition. She could be out of a [[Cecil Beaton]] picture, she could be out of a [[Guy Bourdin]] picture."{{cite journal|last1=Lustig|first1=Jessica|title=A History of Picture-Perfect Icons at DNA|journal=T: The New York Times Style Magazine|date=August 22, 2013|url=http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/08/22/legacy-a-history-of-picture-perfect-icons-at-dna/?_r=0|accessdate=May 5, 2016}} Sozzani, the editor-in-chief of ''Vogue Italia'' recounts that she would receive letters from readers concerned about "what would happen to the magazine if Linda got sick. Because it was all about Linda Evangelista. Her face had the most possibilities."{{cite news|last1=Blanks|first1=Tim|title=Editor Franca Sozzani Is Still in Vogue|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/editor-franca-sozzani-is-still-in-vogue-1407423448|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=August 7, 2014}} Sozzani additionally stated, "For me, she is the model, not only for her beauty, but her attitude, her intelligence." Meisel, to whom Evangelista is his muse, considers her "extraordinarily photogenic". Fashion designer [[John Galliano]] has said that "inspiration hasn't been the same without her. She is an enormous influence on all the photographers and stylists." In his book ''[[Face Forward]]'', the late makeup artist [[Kevyn Aucoin]] said of Evangelista, "I first worked with Linda in the early eighties and have yet to meet another model who was more involved in every aspect of her work. Her specialties were knowing what was best for her hair, makeup, styling, and lighting -- and Linda was always right. It was mind-boggling. Many of the unforgettable images of this haunting beauty were, in great degree, due to her involvement."{{cite book|last1=Aucoin|first1=Kevyn|title=Face Forward|date=2000|publisher=Little, Brown and Company|location=London|isbn=0-316-28644-3|page=144|edition=1st}} A sentiment echoed by fashion stylist Paul Cavaco who described Evangelista as "the greatest collaborator of all time." Evangelista was referred to as "the supermodel’s supermodel" by Marcus Chang of ''[[T: The New York Times Style Magazine]]''.{{cite journal|last1=Chang|first1=Marcus|title=Fashion Yourself Cultured|journal=T: The New York Times Style Magazine|date=September 10, 2009|url=http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/10/showtime-fashion-yourself-cultured/|accessdate=May 5, 2016}} According to Shane Watson of ''[[The Evening Standard]]'', "Of all the supermodels, Linda was most responsible for elevating the job into an art form, pushing up the fees, piling on the expectations and generally ensuring that by the end of the Eighties the world of the top model had become as lucrative, glamorous and shrouded in enigma as that of the Hollywood star",{{cite news|last1=Watson|first1=Shane|title=Vogue's Old Girl; Linda Evangelista Was the World's First Supermodel. Now, at 36, She's Back - Storming the Cover of American Vogue|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-77329022/vogue-s-old-girl-linda-evangelista-was-the-world-s|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=The Evening Standard|date=August 20, 2001|location=London, England}} a statement which perhaps best captures the significance of Evangelista's impact. == Activism and awards == [[File:Linda Evangelista star on Walk of Fame.jpg|thumb|left|Evangelista's star on Canada's Walk of Fame]] Evangelista is an activist for HIV/AIDS research and awareness, as well as for breast cancer research and awareness. She was one of the icons in the Viva Glam campaign for the [[Mac AIDS Fund]]. In October 2013, she was the host of [[amfAR]]'s Inaugural Inspiration Gala in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.{{cite web|title=Goldie Hawn, Linda Evangelista Help Raise More than $600,000 for amfAR at Inaugural Inspiration Gala Rio|url=http://www.amfar.org/in-the-spotlight/press-releases/goldie-hawn,-linda-evangelista-help-raise-more-than-$600,000-for-amfar-at-inaugural-inspiration-gala-rio/|website=amfAR|accessdate=June 13, 2014|date=October 5, 2013}} Evangelista also supports the [[Elton John AIDS Foundation]] and is an advocate for [[LGBT]] concerns.{{cite web|last1=Karimzadeh|first1=Marc|title=Linda Evangelista on MyHabit’s "Give With Style," Philanthropy, and the CFDA|url=http://cfda.com/blog/linda-evangelista-on-myhabits-give-with-style-philanthropy-and-the-cfda|website=Council of Fashion Designers of America|accessdate=April 25, 2016|date=October 7, 2015}} In 1996, she was the recipient of [[VH1]]'s Fashion Awards Lifetime Achievement Award which was presented to her by [[Anna Wintour]], editor-in-chief of ''Vogue''. In June 2003, she received a star on [[Canada's Walk of Fame]] in Toronto. In 2005, she was named as a World Fashion Icon by the [[Women's World Award]]s in Leipzig, Germany. In March 2008, she was chosen as "The Greatest Supermodel of All Time" by a viewer poll for the [[CBC Television]] show ''[[Fashion File]]''.{{cite AV media|date=March 26, 2008|title=Fashion File: Super Linda |medium=Television production|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wGPUIVzaVh4|accessdate=April 29, 2015|publisher=CBC Television|quote=Linda Evangelista wins our viewers' poll as the greatest supermodel of all time.}} == Personal life == === Relationships === In 1987, Evangelista married Gérald Marie, who was the head of the Elite modeling agency's Paris office.{{cite web|title=Linda's Delight As She Confirms Baby News |url=http://www.hellomagazine.com/canada/2006/06/15/lindaevangelista/ |website=Hello Magazine |accessdate=June 13, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714224514/http://www.hellomagazine.com/canada/2006/06/15/lindaevangelista/ |archivedate=July 14, 2014 |df= }}{{cite journal|last1=Sporkin|first1=Elizabeth|title=Falling For The Act|journal=People|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20110429,00.html|date=May 17, 1993|accessdate=June 13, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714155622/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20110429,00.html|archivedate=July 14, 2014|df=mdy-all}} They were divorced in 1993. She also dated actor [[Kyle MacLachlan]], whom she first met on a photoshoot for [[Barneys New York]] in 1992.{{cite journal|last1=Cavendish|first1=Lucy|title=Kyle and the love of his life|journal=Daily Mail|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-184889/Kyle-love-life.html|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} The couple became engaged in 1995 but broke up in 1998.{{cite news|title=Evangelista Moves On After Breakup|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1998-08-01/news/9808010143_1_evangelista-maclachlan-betrothal|work=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=June 13, 2014|date=August 1, 1998}}{{cite journal|title=Fashion Exchange|journal=People|date=August 17, 1998|volume=50|issue=5|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20126021,00.html|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} Afterwards, she dated French soccer player [[Fabien Barthez]]. She became pregnant but miscarried, six months into the pregnancy.{{cite news|last1=Dow|first1=Ian|title=Linda's Feeling Fab as She Plans to Wed Barthez|url=https://www.questia.com/article/1G1-77473499/linda-s-feeling-fab-as-she-plans-to-wed-barthez#/|accessdate=November 26, 2014|work=Daily Record (Glasgow, Scotland)|date=August 24, 2001}} The couple broke up in the year 2000, reunited in 2001, and then officially ended their relationship in 2002. === Child support case === In October 2006, Evangelista gave birth to a son, refusing to name his biological father, sparking rumors.{{cite journal|title=Linda Evangelista profile|journal=Hello! Daily News|url=http://www.hellomagazine.com/profiles/linda-evangelista/|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} While pregnant, she appeared on the August 2006 cover of ''Vogue''. In late June 2011, Evangelista filed court papers that revealed her son was fathered by billionaire Frenchman [[François-Henri Pinault]], who by then was the husband of actress [[Salma Hayek]],{{cite news|last1=Italiano|first1=Laura|title=Salma Hayek's hubby fathered Linda Evangelista's son|url=https://nypost.com/2011/07/01/salma-hayeks-hubby-fathered-linda-evangelistas-son/#ixzz1Qv6zociT|work=New York Post|date=July 1, 2011}}{{cite news|last1=Baker|first1=K.C.|last2=Shira|first2=Dahvi|title=Salma Hayek's Husband, François-Henri Pinault, Is the Father of Linda Evangelista's Son|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20507623,00.html|work=People|date=July 1, 2011|accessdate=May 7, 2012}} and who Evangelista had dated for four months in late 2005 and early 2006.{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Esther|title=Luxury group CEO François-Henri Pinault faces model Linda Evangelista in court|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/hautehouse_row/Luxury-group-CEO-Francois-Henri-Pinault-to-face-model-Linda-Evangelista-in-court.html|accessdate=January 21, 2018|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=May 3, 2012}} After several court appearances aimed at establishing a child-support agreement, on August 1, 2011, Evangelista formally filed for a child support order in Manhattan Family Court, seeking $46,000 in monthly child support from Pinault.{{cite web|last1=Sternberg|first1=Louis|title=Factors in Calculating Child Support – Linda Evangelista seeking $46,000 per month|url=http://www.louislsternberglaw.com/2011/08/02/factors-in-calculating-child-support-linda-evangelista-seeking-46000-per-month-2/|website=Suffolkdivorcelawyer.com|date=August 2, 2011}} It was reported that if granted, this amount "would probably be the largest support order in the history of the family court".{{cite news|last1=Schwartz|first1=Alison|title=Linda Evangelista Wants $46,000 in Monthly Child Support: Report|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20514995,00.html|work=People|date=August 2, 2011|accessdate=May 7, 2012}} A heavily publicized{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Luchina|title=Linda Evangelista Settles Child Custody Case|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/linda-evangelista-settles-child-custody-case/story?id=16296433#.T6WLu45y9JM|website=ABCnews.com|date=May 7, 2012|accessdate=May 7, 2012}} child support trial began on May 3, 2012,{{cite web|last1=Italiano|first1=Laura|title=Pinault and Evangelista child-support trial begins|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/manhattan/pinault_and_evangelista_due_in_court_X29zVJItzZlhM9280XZLtJ|work=New York Post|date=May 3, 2012|accessdate=May 7, 2012}} and included testimony from both Pinault and Evangelista, with Evangelista's attorney claiming that Pinault had never supported the child.{{cite web|title=Linda Evangelista testifies at NYC child-support trial|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Entertainment/20120504/evangelista-child-support-120504/|website=CTVnews.ca|date=May 4, 2012|accessdate=May 7, 2012}}{{cite web|last1=Sternberg|first1=Louis|title=Linda Evangelista's Right to Child Support Prior to Petitioning|url=http://www.louislsternberglaw.com/2012/05/03/linda-evangelistas-child-support-prior-petitioning/|website=Suffolkdivorcelawyer.com|date=May 3, 2012|accessdate=May 8, 2012}} Several days into the trial, on May 7, 2012, Evangelista and Pinault reached an out-of-court settlement.{{cite news|last1=Fleeman|first1=Mike|title=Linda Evangelista Settles Child-Support Case|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20593472,00.html|work=People|date=May 4, 2012|accessdate=May 7, 2012}} ===Religion=== In a 1997 interview, Evangelista said that she was a practicing Roman Catholic and that her favorite book was the [[Bible]].[https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/interview-linda-evangelista-i-will-survive-1252761.html] == Filmography == {| class="wikitable {{Quran}} This page is a '''List of people related to Quranic verses''': ==Ahl al-Bayt== The [[Ahl al-Bayt]] was Muhammads household. Shi'a and Sunni have differing views regarding who is included among them, and also different views regarding which verses are associated with the household. ===Generally=== ====3:61==== {{See also|Hadith of Mubahela}}
''And whoso disputeth with thee concerning him, after the knowledge which hath come unto thee, say (unto him): Come! We will summon our sons and your sons, and our women and your women, and ourselves and yourselves, then we will pray humbly (to our Lord) and (solemnly) invoke the curse of Allah upon those who lie.''{{cite quran|3|61}}
According to [[hadith]] collections, in 631 an [[Arab Christians|Arab Christian]] envoy from [[Najran]] (currently in northern [[Yemen]] and partly in [[Saudi Arabia]]) came to Muhammad to argue which of the two parties erred in its doctrine concerning [[Jesus]]. After likening Jesus' miraculous birth to Adam's creation,{{cite quran|3|59|style = ref}} Muhammad called them to ''mubahala'' (cursing), where each party should ask God to destroy the lying party and their families.{{cite quran|3|61|style = ref}} Muhammad, to prove to them that he is a prophet, brought his daughter Fatimah and his surviving grandchildren, [[Hasan ibn Ali]] and [[Husayn ibn Ali]], and Ali ibn Abi Talib and came back to the Christians and said this is my family and covered himself and his family with a cloak.See:* [[Sahih Muslim]], Chapter of virtues of companions, section of virtues of Ali, 1980 Edition Pub. in Saudi Arabia, Arabic version, v4, p1871, the end of tradition #32 * Sahih al-Tirmidhi, v5, p654 * Madelung, 1997, pp. 15 and 16 [[Allameh Tabatabaei]] explains in ''[[Tafsir al-Mizan]]'' that the word "Our selves" in this verse refers to Muhammad and Ali. Then he narrates [[Imam Ali al-Rida]], eighth [[Twelve Imams|Shia Imam]], in discussion with [[Al-Ma'mun]], [[Abbasid]] [[caliph]], referred to this verse to prove the superiority of Muhammad's progeny over the rest of the [[Ummah|Muslim community]], and considered it as the proof for Ali's right for caliphate due to Allah made Ali like the self of Muhammad.[http://www.almizan.org/Tafseer/Volume6/6Imran2.asp Tabatabaei, Tafsir al-Mizan, v.6, Al Imran, verses 61-63] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090814141005/http://almizan.org/Tafseer/Volume6/6Imran2.asp |date=2009-08-14 }} ====33:33==== {{main|Ahl al-Bayt|The verse of purification}} {{See also|Hadith of The Cloak|Hadith of the Twelve Successors}} Surah Al-Ahzaab, Ayah 33:
"...Verily, Allah has decreed to remove fault from you, O' Ahlul Bayt, and sanctify you in a perfect way."
Sunni view: "No! It's taken out of context, it's only talking about the wives of the Prophet!" Firstly, it is important to note that nowhere in this Ayah are the wives of Muhammad mentioned. Surah Al-Ahzaab, Full Ayah 33:
"Stay in your houses and do not display your finery with the display of the former [days of] ignorance. Maintain the prayer and pay the zakat and obey Allah and His Apostle. Verily, Allah has decreed to remove fault from you, O' Ahlul Bayt, and sanctify you in a perfect way."
Each [[Ayah]] is an individual sign of Allah: "Ayah or Aayah is the Arabic word for evidence or sign: "These are the Ayat (proofs, evidences, verses, lessons, revelations, etc.) of Allah, which We recite to you (O Muhammad) with truth. Then in which speech after Allah and His Ayat will they believe?" (Surah Al-Jathiya 45:6) Secondly, this Ayah uses the words Ankum (from you) and Yutahhirakum (to purify you), which are both in the masculine plural form. Though it is known that in Arabic Masculine is unisex, there is a problem saying that since the fact that the previous sentence in reference to the wives used only feminine verbs and pronouns, while this sentences uses masculine. The feminine for the above would be Ankunna and Yutahhirakunna. The sudden change in grammatical gender reference means that it is not about the wives. Similar use of switching subjects after Ayahs are found all throughout the Quran. A great example of this is Surah Haqqah, which does so in nearly every Ayah. Thirdly, Muhammad said explicitly that wives are not part of Ahlul Bayt: Sahih Muslim, one of the three most authentic collections in the Sunnah.
Sahih Muslim #31:5920-2: "Hussain Ibn Sabrah asked Zaid Ibn Arqam, "Who are the members of His household? Aren't His wives part of the members of his family?" Thereupon Zaid said, "His wives are members of his family [in a general sense], but (Islamically), the members of his family are those for whom acceptance of zakat is forbidden." Hussain asked, "Who are they?". Upon which Zaid said, "Ali and the offspring of Ali, Aqil and the offspring of Aqil, the offspring of Jaffer, and the offspring of Abbas." Hussain said "These are those for whom the acceptance of zakat is forbidden?" Zaid replied, "Yes."
According to Sahih Muslim, Zaid then expanded on this hadith and stated this:
Hussain Then asked: "Aren't the wives (Of the Prophet) included amongst the members of the household?" He said, "No, by Allah, a woman lives with a man [as his wife] for a certain period; he then divorces her, and she goes back to her parents and her people. The members of his household include his own self, and his kith, and kin, for whom the acceptance of zakat is prohibited." - Sahih Muslim #31:5923
===[[Ali ibn Abu Talib]]=== {{main|Ali in the Quran}} Before Shia & Sunni Ali is the one of Alh al-Bayt. Ali is the fourth Sunni Caliph and first Shia Imam. ====2.207====
''And among men is he who sells his ''[[nafs]]'' (self) in exchange for the pleasure of [[Allah]]''{{cite quran|2|207}}

'''Manuel Ignacio Santa Cruz Loidi''' ({{lang-eu|Manuel Santa Krutz}}) (1842-1926) was a [[Spanish people|Spanish]] [[Roman Catholicism|Roman-Catholic]] [[priest]]. For some 35 years he served on apostolic mission in [[Colombia]], where he was heading a parish in rural interior of the [[Pasto, Colombia|Pasto province]]; for some 15 years he held also various minor posts in [[Jamaica]]. He is best known, however, for his activity in 1872-1873, when he commanded a [[Carlist]] [[guerilla]] unit during the [[Third Carlist War|civil war]] in [[Spain]]. As "cura Santa Cruz" (priest Santa Cruz) or simply as "El Cura" (The Priest) he gained notoriety for cruelty and in the Spanish public discourse of the late 19th century he became a symbol of savage brutality. In this role – though also with a grade of ambiguity - he featured as a protagonist in a few great works of Spanish [[Modernist literature|Modernist]] literature of the early 20th century and became a mythical figure long before his own death.
==Family and youth== [[File:Vista de la localidad de Elduaien (1 de 1) - Fondo Marín-Kutxa Fototeka.jpg|thumb|left|[[Elduain]]]] Manuel Santa Cruz Loidi was descendant to [[Basque people|Basque]] rural working class families; generations of his ancestors were farmers living in the [[Oria (river)|Oria river]] valley, in the [[Gipuzkoa|Gipuzkoan]] county of [[Tolosa, Spain|Tolosa]]. His paternal grandfather [[Pascual de Santa Cru]]z was a native of [[Andoain|Andoain]] yet he settled in [[Elduain]], probably on the economy of his wife María Bautista Sarove. Their son and the father of Manuel Ignacio, [[Francisco Antonio Santa Cruz Sarove]] (1784-1842), in 1824 married Juana Josefa Loidi Urrestarazu (1803-1871); she was the daughter of Miguel Ignacio Loidi, a native of [[Amezketa]], and María Ignacia Urrestarazu, who originated from [[Orendain]].<ref>Juan de Olazabal y Ramery, ''El Cura Santa Cruz Guerrillero'', San Sebastián 1979, p. 71, referred after Iñigo Pérez de Rada Cavanilles, ''La Partida del Cura Santa Cruz y su Bandera'', [in:] ''Noticias Carlistas'' service, 16.06.2011, available [http://noticiascarlistas.blogspot.com/2011/06/la-partida-del-cura-santa-cruz-y-su.html here]</ref> The couple lived in Elduain; their [[Baserri|caserio]], known as Zamonea, was among the poorer ones in the village.<ref> Gaëtan Bernoville, ''La cruz sangrienta. Historia del cura Santa Cruz'', Tafalla 2000, {{ISBN|848136181X}}, p. 18</ref> It is not clear how many children they had, though according to some sources Manuel Ignacio was not their only child and he had at least one sister.<ref> unknown by name, a sister of Manuel Santa Cruz was reportedly a protagonist of one of his wartime episodes, exchanged for a Liberal official</ref> Following the death of her husband María Ignacia re-married with a widower Juan Ignacio Betelu Muñagorri (1795-1861); it is not clear whether they had any offspring.<ref> Pérez de Rada Cavanilles 2011</ref>
Manuel was raised by his mother and [[step-father]] and initially did not differ from other village boys. It is not clear where he was first educated; at some stage he was taken care of by his much older paternal cousin, a local priest Francisco Antonio Sasiain Santa Cruz (1812-1898); he taught the teenager [[Latin-language|Latin]] and apparently directed him towards the religious career.<ref> according to some sources Francisco Antonio Sasiain Santa Cruz was the uncle of Manuel Santa Cruz, Bernoville 2000, p. 18</ref> Indeed in 1861 Manuel entered the [[seminary]] in [[Vitoria-Gasteiz|Vitoria]]; during the first 3 years he was obtaining high grades and was rewarded with the ''meritissimus'' title; later his performance worsened, reportedly due to health problems.<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 20</ref> He was ordained as a priest in 1866 and posted to [[Hernialde]], a village few miles from his native one. According to some sources he was first nominated a [[coadjutor]],<ref>Pérez de Rada Cavanilles 2011</ref> other authors claim he initially acted as a [[vicar]].<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 20</ref> Following death of the [[parish priest]] it was Santa Cruz who became his successor at unspecified time in the late 1860s; he allegedly assumed his duties with frenetic energy and as a spiritual shepherd he tended to rigidity, himself adhering to an austere living pattern. [[File:Curasantacruz.png|thumb|160px|Santa Cruz, 1870]] Since his father had served as a Carlist volunteer during the [[First Carlist War|last civil war]]<ref>Pérez de Rada Cavanilles 2011</ref> and since legitimist sympathies prevailed among the rural Gipuzkoan folk<ref> compare e.g. the Basque folk rhymes, gathered in Antoni Zavala (ed.), ''Karlisten Bigarren Gerrateko bertsoak'', Oiartzun 1997, {{ISBN|8489080585}}</ref> it is likely that Manuel from his youth was growing in an ambience strongly flavored with Carlism.<ref> Bernoville 2000, pp. 17-20</ref> His position was probably strengthened during the seminar years, as Carlism was popular also among the lower and regular clergy of the province.<ref> Basque and Navarrese seminars and religious orders of the time are considered "foco de integrismo religioso", Iñaki Anasagasti, ''El cura Santa Cruz'', [in:] ''Ianasagasti'' blog service, available [http://ianasagasti.blogs.com/mi_blog/2017/04/el-cura-santa-cruz.html here], see also Juan Cruz Labeaga Mendiola, ''Memorias de exilio de un clérigo carlista (1858-1869)'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 59 (1998), p.829</ref> In line with [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] outlook Santa Cruz assumed a decisively hostile stand towards the [[Glorious Revolution (Spain)|1868 revolution]], from behind the pulpit lambasting the new regime as an ungodly depraved system.<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 27</ref> His inflammatory sermons gained him attention of the authorities; in October 1870 a [[Guardia Civil|Guardia Civi]]l patrol<ref> details of the episode differ; some authors claim there were just two civiles, see e.g. Bernoville 2000, p. 27; other maintain there were some 20-30 officials deployed to detain Santa Cruz, Roman Oyarzun, ''La historia del carlismo'', Madrid 1969, p. 331</ref> showed up in Hernialde to detain him after a Sunday mass. Santa Cruz took advantage of somewhat loose approach of his captors and fled, in few days crossing to France.<ref> the escape served as the first in a long string of anecdotes which used to build the later Santa Cruz’ legend. When approached by the civiles by the end of the mass Santa Cruz asked whether he could have breakfast and suggested that they have some chocolate with him. As they declined Santa Cruz led them to the clergy house and left both at the ground floor, going upstair allegedly to change. He then jumped out of the first floor window, Bernoville 2000, pp. 27-28</ref>
==Guerilla leader== [[File:Carlist guerilla 1873.jpg|thumb|left|Santa Cruz and his men, 1873]] Following some 18 months on exile in [[Bayonne]]<ref> Juantxo Egaña, ''Las imágenes de Ladislas Konarzewski'', [in:] ''juantxoegaña'' service 31.12.09, available [http://juantxoegana.blogspot.com/search?q=cura+santa+cruz here] </ref> in 1872-1873 Santa Cruz was taking part in the guerilla warfare prior and during the [[Third Carlist War]]. His record falls into 4 separate strings: from April till May 1872,<ref>when the unit of his commander Recondo surrendered in May 1872 Santa Cruzed refused to follow suit and fled</ref> from June till August 1872,<ref>in August 1872 he was captured by governmental troops; he managed to escape from a building in Aramaio he was held at from the balcony and then spent many hours (numbers given vary up to "the whole day") under a bridge in the ice-cold river, for long periods all under water and breathing with a straw; he then made it to the French border. Except the Enderlaza carnage the Aramaio episode is probably the best-known chapter of Santa Cruz' wartime history and the key one building his myth. For one of the accounts see Bernoville 2000, pp. 45-49</ref> from December 1872 till July 1873<ref>the first half of 1873 was the climax of Santa Cruz' activity, with some 20 belligerent episodes noted between January and June; he decided to abandon arms under pressure from the Carlist high command</ref> and in December 1873,<ref>following few idle months in the French Pyrenees Santa Cruz gave in to the pressure of his men and returned to arms, but December 1873 was pretty uneventful and following another showdown with Lizarraga ended with the last and ultimate withdrawal into France</ref> all separated by periods of taking refuge in France. Initially he joined a unit led by a Carlist veteran Pedro Recondo; serving as a [[chaplain]], Santa Cruz was gaining experience in rural irregular tactics. Since the summer of 1872 he was leading his own troops; initially the group consisted of some 15–25 men, but later it grew and in literature is estimated at 200,<ref>''Narración militar de la guerra carlista de 1869 à 1876'', Madrid 1883, p. 370</ref> 500 or even 1,000, with an informal in-between command structure built up. The detachment was rather loosely incorporated into the Carlist war effort; at early stages it was assigned a vague task of "guarding the Northern borderline" by the legitimist [[general staff]], yet it seems that the unit retained great autonomy and operated independently.
In military terms the activity of Santa Cruz’ unit consisted of harassing the enemy logistics network and raiding minor garrisons.<ref>according to a contemporary historian the unit of Santa Cruz "was among the most efficient ones" when it comes to sabotage actions, Jose Andres-Gallego (ed.), ''Historia general de España y América'' vol. XVI/2, Madrid 1981, {{ISBN|8432121142}}, p. 253</ref> The former included disrupting postal service,<ref>by ambushes against postal stagecoaches or destroying postal stations</ref> arms transports<ref>e.g. on August 6, 1872 Santa Cruz and his unit ambushed an arms transport from Mondragón, seizing some 50 Berdan and Remington rifles, see ''Narración militar de la guerra carlista de 1869 à 1876'', Madrid 1883, p. 202</ref> or railway connections;<ref>the unit of Santa Cruz was derailing trains and demolishing railway terminals, e.g. on January 18, 1873 the Santa Cruz unit attacked the railway station in Hernani and burnt it down </ref> the latter included descending upon smaller locations<ref>e.g. in June 1872 he took control of [[Azcoitia]] or in February 1873 he raided [[Deba, Gipuzkoa|Deva]]</ref> and destroying archives, pillaging [[Guardia Civil]] or [[Carabineros]] posts, abducting local officials and staging shows of prowess. The Liberal high command was forced to diminish their frontline strength and to assign more troops to vigilance and patrol duties. However, in line with his guerilla strategy Santa Cruz avoided open confrontation against enemy forces; cases of accepting a battle usually resulted in defeat, e.g. in [[Aia]].<ref>for detailed though apparently biased acoount, which portrays the Aia episode as a treason on part of Lizarraga, see Bernovilla 2000, pp. 69-79</ref> When facing enemy roundup Santa Cruz used to disband his group and to set re-assembly terms; taking advantage of perfect familiarity with the mountainous Gipuzkoan countryside and support of the local population, he kept evading the governmental chase. Santa Cruz operated across all the province of Gipuzkoa, though he was noted also in neighboring areas of [[Biscay (province)|Biscay]],<ref>e.g. in August 1872 Santa Cruz operated in the region of [[Arrazola]], Iñaki Anasagasti, ''Algunas peripecias del cura Santa Cruz'', [in:] ''Ianasagasti'' blog service, available [http://ianasagasti.blogs.com/mi_blog/2012/10/algunas-peripecias-del-cura-santa-cruz.html here]</ref> [[Álava]] and particularly [[Navarre]].<ref>in the Navarrese town of Vera de Bidasoa he set up one of his headquarters</ref> [[File:Enderlaza 2016.jpg|thumb|Enderlaza, 2016]] Since early 1873 Santa Cruz gained notoriety for cruelty and was charged with committing acts of barbarity.<ref>his unit sported a "guerra sin cuartel" ("no-mercy war") banner with skull and bones insignia</ref> They consisted of executions of prisoners,<ref>tha case which caused particular outrage was abduction and later execution of a mayor of Anoeta, Anjel Rekalde, ''Dorregarai: la casa torre'', Tafalla 1992, {{ISBN|9788486597511}}, p. 110</ref> including women<ref>allegedly Santa Cruz twice spared a woman he charged with spying; when detained for the third time, she was eventually executed, Bernoville 2000, p. 88</ref> or members of his own unit when suspected of treason, burning down settlements or administering corporal punishment.<ref>in later literature he was charged with ordering humiliating sanctions, also against females, see e.g. references in ''Gerifaltes de antaño'' by Ramón Valle-Inclan or ''Zalacain el aventurero'' by Pio Baroja, who suggest that Santa Cruz used to subject women to [[tarring and feathering]]; however, the information is not confirmed in scientific historiography</ref> The episode which caused particular outrage occurred in June 1873, when santacrucistas assaulted a fortified provincial border control post in Endarlaza.<ref>for the best account available see Mikelatz , ''Los Fusilamientos de Endarlaza: Crónica de un Desastre Anunciado'', [in:] ''Hechos, Anécdotas y Relatos de Las Guerras Carlistas'' service 10.12.16, available [http://mikelatz.blogspot.com/2016/12/los-fusilamientos-de-endarlaza-cronica.html here]</ref> Claiming that during the shootout the defenders had mischievously displayed a white flag to fire at the approaching Carlists later on, Santa Cruz had his men execute 35 carabineros who had ultimately surrendered. The Carlist high command was continuously uneasy about Santa Cruz;<ref>the Carlist general staff was getting perplexed by activity of Santa Cruz for a number of reasons. His independent military actions might have triggered moves of large Liberal troops which in turn might have caught regular Carlist units by surprise. Brutality of El Cura damaged reputation of the claimant, especially that he posed as representative of godly law and order. Still worse, Santa Cruz undermined the credibility of Carlist high command; they have concluded deals with local railway companies and Santa Cruz’s actions against the infrastructure, like derailing trains or burning terminals, was causing trouble</ref> the Enderlaza episode proved to be the last straw.<ref>Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8420639478}}, p. 180</ref> The local legitimist commander general Antonio Lizarraga, who was trying to bring Santa Cruz in line for some time, demanded that the insubordinate priest backs down. Eventually Santa Cruz found himself hunted down by the Liberals and the Carlists alike; he disbanded his unit and withdrew into France.<ref>Santa Cruz does not elicit much interest from present-day historians. For a brief and unbiased recent account of his wartime deeds and later reception by a professional historian see Canal 2000, pp. 179-182. The latest larger study on Santa Cruz, Vicente Garmendia, ''Memorias levemente apocrifas del cura Santa Cruz'', San Sebastian 2007, {{ISBN|9788497972345}}, is basically focused on dismantling the myth of Santa Cruz</ref>
==France, Britain and Jamaica== [[File:Carlos Duke of Madrid.jpg|thumb|left|160px|[[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]]]] In France Santa Cruz seemed disoriented and with no direction;<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 145</ref> he spent more than a year mostly in small villages in the [[French Basque country]].<ref> Santa Cruz was hosted either by former members of his unit or by his acquaintances, Bernoville 2000, pp. 145-146</ref> Some of his former men suggested resumption of warfare, though Lizarraga confirmed that in such case he would be persecuted.<ref> Bernoville 2000, pp. 146-147</ref> The Madrid government filed a request for extradition, turned down by the French.<ref> ''La Correspondencia de España'' 19.07.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7146612&interno=S&posicion=4&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[National Gendarmerie|Gendarmarie]] kept a close watch on him and at one point Santa Cruz was detained in [[Bayonne]];<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 148</ref> he was pressed to leave the country. In late 1874 or early 1875 he found himself in the [[Jesuit]] college in [[Lille]]; thanks to support of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cambrai|Cambrai archbishop]] [[:fr:René-François Régnier|René-François Régnier]] Santa Cruz’s plea for clemency was accepted in the [[Holy See|Vatican]] and he was reinstated to regular religious duty,<ref> Bernoville 2000, pp. 148-149</ref> abandoned during the wartime years.<ref> when leading the guerilla unit Santa Cruz did not conduct regular religious service; there was another chaplain in his unit, who was taking care of sermons, confessions, funerals etc.</ref> He intended to commence [[Christian mission|missionary service]];<ref> according to later accounts of his guerilla subordinates already in 1874 Santa Cruz declared he was no longer a military commander but rather a missionary, and took some preparatory steps for would-be service in [[Americas|America]], Bernoville 2000, pp. 146-147</ref> as part of preparation scheme the Jesuits directed him to their establishment in [[Great Britain|Britain]], where Santa Cruz was to learn [[English language|English]]. In early 1876 he met his king [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]] in [[London]] but accounts differ;<ref>for an ambiguous account see Julio de Urquijo, ''La Cruz de Sangre. El Cura Santa Cruz, pequeña rectificación histórica'', San Sebastián 1928, pp. 61-62, referred after Pérez de Rada Cavanilles 2011</ref> according to some Santa Cruz defended his wartime record,<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 150</ref> according to others he regretted his conduct and begged for mercy.<ref>during the London meeting Carlos VII, who during the war authorised orders against Santa Cruz and called him a traitor, pardoned Santa Cruz, [[Francisco Martín Melgar y Rodríguez|Francisco Melgar]], ''Veinte años con Don Carlos. Memorias de su secretario'', Madrid 1940, p. 83, similar account in [[Manuel Polo y Peyrolon]], ''D. Carlos de Borbón y de Austria-Easte'', Valencia 1909, p. 56</ref> Shortly afterwards he sailed to [[Jamaica]].<ref> one source claims also that his trip was made possible by donation of "a pious English lady", Bernoville 2000, p. 150</ref> The Catholic administration of the island since the 1840s has been dominated by the English Jesuit province and since the 1860s their activity was on the rise;<ref> in 1866 there were 4,110 Catholics in Jamaica, two thirds of them in Kingston, Kathryn Wirtenberger, ''The Jesuits in Jamaica'' [MA thesis Loyola University], Chicago 1942, p. 66</ref> Santa Cruz was dispatched in a group of 3 priests.<ref> Francis J. Osborne, ''History of the Catholic Church in Jamaica'', Austin 1977, {{ISBN|9780829405446}}, p. 264</ref> [[File:Cane cutters in Jamaica.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Cane (grass)|cane]] cutters, Jamaica]] Upon crossing the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] Santa Cruz abandoned the first surname and started using only his maternal one; hence, in America he became known as Manuel Loidi. In December 1876 he was first recorded as performing religious service in Jamaica;<ref> ''Roman Catholic Baptisms 1876'', [in:] ''Jamaican Family Search Genealogy'' service, available [http://www.jamaicanfamilysearch.com/Members/c/Cb76d-j.htm here] </ref> he was later to serve in the parishes of [[Saint Andrew Parish, Jamaica|St. Andrews]], [[Portland Parish|Portland]] and [[Saint Mary Parish, Jamaica|St. Mary]], all located in the Eastern part of the island.<ref> ''Handbook of Jamaica 1891-1892, The Church of England and Roman Catholics'', [in:] ''Jamaican Family Search Genealogy'' service, available [http://www.jamaicanfamilysearch.com/Members/h/hclergy1.htm here]; a religious identified as "E. Loidi" is almost certainly Santa Cruz, as at that time there were no more than 10 Catholic religious on the island</ref> His exact position in the religious structure is not clear; in documentation available he is listed as "clergyman";<ref> ''The Church of England and Roman Catholics'', [in:] ''Jamaican Family Search Genealogy'' service, available [http://www.jamaicanfamilysearch.com/Members/h/hclergy1.htm here]</ref> until the early 1880s he is recorded usually as administering baptisms,<ref> see ''Baptisms'' section, ''Roman Catholic Baptisms (A-J). King’s Weston'', [in:] ''Jamaican Family Search Genealogy'' service, available [http://www.jamaicanfamilysearch.com/Members/c/Cbweston_a-j.htm here]</ref> marriages<ref> see ''Marriages'' section, ''Roman Catholic Baptisms (K-Y). King’s Weston'', [in:] ''Jamaican Family Search Genealogy'' service, available [http://www.jamaicanfamilysearch.com/Members/c/Cbweston_k-y.htm here] </ref> and especially funerals,<ref> ''Roman Catholic Burials'', [in:] ''Jamaican Family Search Genealogy'' service, available [http://www.jamaicanfamilysearch.com/Members/c/Cbu17j-y.htm here] </ref> mostly though not exclusively in the location of King’s Weston. At one point or another he served in 5 different mission stations and himself founded the other nine.<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 150</ref> Today he is particularly noted for his work in the small Preston Hill village, one of the first Catholic congregations outside [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]]<ref> Wirtenberger 1942, p. 63</ref> and inhabited mostly by descendants of the Castle Mine slaves. Santa Cruz is credited for construction of a wooden St. Francis Xavier church, which served the faithful for decades.<ref> Michael Burke, ''500 Years of Christianity in Jamaica'', [in:] ''Jamaica Observer'' 26.04.12, available [http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/columns/500-years-of-christianity-in-jamaica_11339616 here]</ref> It seems that Santa Cruz and the Jamaica Jesuits lived in extreme poverty, as destitute and barren local Catholic community was hardly in position to support them.<ref> in 1887 one Jesuit missionary noted: "We are all as poor as can be. Once in the country a piece of honeycomb was sent in for my breakfast, with a request that I would return the wax. Very few of them own beds; they sleep on a mat on the ground”, Wirtenberger 1942, p. 91; others mention that Santa Cruz lived in "austeridad", "rigidez" and lack of "cualquier clase de comodidad", Bernoville 2000, p. 150</ref> It is not clear why Santa Cruz abandoned Jamaica in 1891 or 1892; it is likely that his leaving the island was related to change in missionary administration, as in the early 1890s the Jamaica mission was allotted to the [[Maryland]]-[[New York City|New York]] Jesuit province and soon the US Jesuits took over.<ref> Wirtenberger 1942, p. 92</ref>
==Colombia== [[File:Panoramica Pasto volcan galeras.JPG|thumb|left|[[Pasto]], present view]] It is not clear in what circumstances Santa Cruz moved to Colombia; one version is that the option was suggested and facilitated by an anonymous influential Spanish Jesuit and a friend of him.<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 151</ref> Santa Cruz was agreed to join Colegio Javieriano,<ref> though the Jesuit college in Pasto existed since 1772, it opened a secondary school module in 1885, see ''Historia'', [in:] ''Colegio Javierano'' web service, available [http://www.javeriano.edu.co/index.php/institucional-2/historia/ here]</ref> which served as a Jesuit college and a seminary in [[Pasto]], a capital of [[Nariño Department|Nariño department]]. He arrived in the city in 1892, possibly having spent some time in [[Panama]] earlier.<ref> Francisco Celis Alban, ''De terrorista a santo'', [in:] ''El Tiempo'' 14.12.2003, available [http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1049478 here]</ref> In the college he was teaching English, French, Latin,<ref> Celis Alban 2003</ref> geography and math;<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 152</ref> his worn-out [[cassock]] and a long beard made him look like a beggar.<ref> Isidoro Medina Patiño, ''Don Manuel: el temible cura guerrillero'', Bogota 2005, {{ISBN|9789583372285}}, referred after Celis Alban 2003</ref> He was not member of the Jesuit order; his request for admission was turned down, reportedly because his wartime deeds required a long penitence period. Santa Cruz was allowed to enter the monastery and to follow the rules, but his formal admission was adjourned until an unspecified later date.<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 151</ref>
Santa Cruz taught in Pasto at least until 1898.<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 152</ref> The following year Colombia was torn by a [[Thousand Days' War|Thousand Days’ War]], with Pasto turned into a Conservative stronghold dominated by personalities of [[Ezequiél Moreno y Díaz|Ezequiel Moreno Díaz]] and [[:es:Pedro Schumacher Niessen|Pedro Schumacher]], two hardline bishops.<ref> Celis Alban 2003</ref> According to a Colombian historian both hierarchs approached Santa Cruz, who was known for uncompromising anti-[[Liberalism|liberal]] sermons. Santa Cruz was reportedly asked to lead operations against the Liberal insurgents, yet he declined. However, he apparently agreed to assist in some kind of staff work, offering his advice in terms of planning and strategy; in this role he turned very successful.<ref> Celis Alban 2003</ref> [[File:Cura Santa Cruz a caballo.png|thumb|160px|Santa Cruz in Colombia]] Following the ultimate Conservative victory in 1902 Santa Cruz founded a village of San Ignacio,<ref> ''La Compañia de Jesús en Pasto, 1599-1985'', Pasto 1985, p. 155</ref> located in the [[Andes]] some 20 km north of Pasto in the county of [[Buesaco]];<ref> Iñaki Anasagasti, ''El aporte vasco contemporáneo en Colombia'', [in:] ''Ianasagasti'' blog service, available [http://ianasagasti.blogs.com/mi_blog/2018/03/el-aporte-vasco-contempor%C3%A1neo-en-colombia.html here]</ref> for the second time since the Hernialde spell he assumed the role of a [[parson]]. The hamlet was inhabited by extremely poor indigenous population; it seems that apart from providing spiritual service, Santa Cruz tried to support it economically. Teaching the locals agriculture, he travelled across the county begging, with the money collected dedicated to needs of the San Ignacio natives.<ref> Celis Alban 2003</ref> Santa Cruz spent some 18 uneventful years in San Ignacio<ref> it is not clear whether Santa Cruz resided permanently in San Ignacio or whether he used to come to the village on Fridays, his arrival announced by a small trumpet he kept since his Gipuzkoan wartime years, ''Páginas escolares'' 264 (1927), p. 4, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000002540&interno=S&presentacion=pagina&posicion=4 here]</ref> and according to some sources was greatly respected among the locals for his apostolic work but also for his personal humility and exemplary life;<ref> ''Una fundación colombiana reivindica la vida de entrega del Cura Santa Cruz, guerrillero vasco del XIX que vivió durante más de tres décadas en Colombia'', [in:] ''Euskalkultura'' service 30.12.2003, available [http://www.euskalkultura.com/espanol/noticias/una-fundacion-colombiana-reivindica-la-vida-de-entrega-del-cura-santa-cruz-guerrillero-vasco-del-xix-que-vivio-durante-mas-de-tres-decadas-en-colombia-1 here]</ref> his most lasting achievement was construction of the local San Ignacio church.<ref> ''Campaña para recuperar capilla de Cura Santa Cruz Loydi'', [in:] ''YouTube service'', available [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R6jZgOPuBi0 here]</ref>
Santa Cruz retained his reactionary ultra-conservative outlook; during local electoral campaigns he used to instruct his flock how to dodge the corrupted election system and vote the candidates he considered right.<ref> Gustavo Jiménez Cadena, ''Es buen negocio vender su voto?'' [in:] ''Ecos de Pasto 740 KHz'' service, available [http://www.emisoraecosdepasto740.com/11-noticias/162-es-buen-negocio-vender-su-voto here]</ref> It seems that he also remained a Carlist; he corresponded with his oldtime war comrades back in Spain<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 153</ref> and in a separate letter pledged loyalty to [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]],<ref> Juan María Roma (ed.), ''Album histórico del carlismo'', Barcelona 1933, p. 241</ref> though there are suggestions he also recognized [[Alfonso XIII of Spain|Don Alfonso]].<ref> ''Páginas escolares'' 264 (1927), p. 4, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000002540&interno=S&presentacion=pagina&posicion=4 here]</ref> In 1920 he was eventually admitted to the Jesuit [[novitiate]] and in 1922 he formally entered the order.<ref> Bernoville 2000, p. 154</ref> It is not clear where Santa Cruz spent his senility; in the Pasto monastery or in San Ignacio, where he was eventually buried in the church he constructed.<ref>slightly other dates are provided in Martin Ugalde Orradre, ''Nueva Síntesis de la historia del pueblo vasco'', Donostia 2010, {{ISBN|9788498432312}}; the author claims that Santa Cruz worked on mission in Colombia from 1891 (not 1892) till 1922, when he retired to monastery life</ref>
==Black legend== [[File:Carlismo Caricatura de 1870.jpg|thumb|left|Santa Cruz in caricature?<ref>the cartoon appeared in September 1870 issue of an anti-religious and anti-clerical magazine ''La Flaca''. Some authors claim it represents Santa Cruz, see Pérez de Rada Cavanilles 2011. It does not seem impossible, given few weeks later Guardia Civil was sent to detain Santa Cruz</ref>]] Since January 1873 the press<ref>mostly Spanish, though also the foreign one; in Britain ''Harper's Weekly'' agonized about "a priest who has won a terrible renown by his unsparing cruelty", ''Harper's Weekly'' 03.05.73, available [https://books.google.es/books?id=4ySERiKHkb4C&pg=PA369&dq=cura+santa+cruz&hl=pl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjfhOn3sY_aAhW0yKYKHcDXCQsQ6AEIODAC#v=onepage&q=cura%20santa%20cruz&f=true here]. However, some English titles without renouncing their utmost hostility sort of advanced kind of romantic gloom of a rebel, e.g. naming Santa Cruz "[[Jack Sheppard]] of Gipuzkoa", ''The Atenaeum'' 11.04.74, available [https://books.google.es/books?id=rT4xAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA486&dq=cura+santa+cruz&hl=pl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzi_imrY_aAhWGC5oKHd4DDzQQ6AEIVDAG#v=onepage&q=cura%20santa%20cruz&f=false here] </ref> reported misdeeds of Santa Cruz,<ref>for a list of crimes he was charged with see ''El Motin'' 25.11.09, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001175151&page=8 here]</ref> dubbed assassin, criminal or barbarian.<ref>"barbarian" – ''La Iberia'' 06.03.73, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001364868&page=2 here], "assassin" – ''El Imparcial'' 13.01.73, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000496025&page=2 here], "bloody priest" – ''El Imparcial'' 05.03.73, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000497362&page=3 here], responsible for crimes – ''La Iberia'' 22.01.73, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001363052&page=3 here], and ferocities – ''Revista de España'' 1873, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002806230&page=262 here]; in early 1873 he was already "tristemente celebre", ''El Periodico para Todos'' 13 (1873), available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003438734&page=15 here]</ref> In 1874-1876 newspapers speculated about his re-entry into war.<ref> some titles claimed he had been noticed in specific locations in Spain and was to assume command, ''La Epoca'' 03.12.1874, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000328821&page=3 here]</ref> In the late 1870s media lost track of him until he was located in Jamaica in the mid-1880s,<ref> ''El Motín'' 25.11.86, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001136416&page=2 here]</ref> and his name reverberated as a memory of past atrocities. In 1880 he became one of key protagonists of ''Vida, hechos y hazañas del famoso bandido y cabecilla Rosa Samaniego'',<ref> Amelina Correa Ramón, ''Otra novela histórica del carlismo: La sima de Igúzquiza (1888)'', [in:] Angeles Ezama et al. (ed.), ''Aún aprendo. Estudios dedicados al profesor Leonardo Romero Tobar'', Zaragoza 2012, {{ISBN|9788415538233}}. p. 286</ref> a short [[novel]] written by an unidentified author. The book portrayed Santa Cruz as a bloody ringleader; with many fictitious episodes<ref> e.g. the novel linked Santa Cruz to Rosa Samaniego, while in fact the two commanders have never met</ref> it became very popular and was re-published until the early 1890s.<ref> the last identified re-edition is form 1893, compare ''GoogleBooks'' service, available [https://books.google.es/books/about/Vida_hechos_y_hazanas_del_famoso_bandido.html?id=IX5LtAEACAAJ&redir_esc=y here]</ref> In the press Santa Cruz was not infrequently mentioned also as a sample of treacherous clergy.<ref> another religious man usually listed together with Santa Cruz as a sample of disloyal priest was the bishop of Urgel, see e.g. ''Las Dominicales'' 15.08.84, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002615915&page=2 here]</ref> From time to time he was reported back in Europe;<ref> ''La Correspondencia de España'' 20.12.88, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000333783&page=3 here]</ref> as speculations about [[:es:Sublevación carlista de octubre de 1900|another Carlist insurgency]] were on the rise in the late 1890s Santa Cruz was even reported seen in Spain.<ref> e.g. in 1897 Santa Cruz was reported seen in Bilbao, ''El Día'' 13.02.97, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002371183&page=2 here], and in Oyarzun, see ''La Epoca'' 21.02.97, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000620897&page=2 here]. The Carlist hierarchs felt compelled to dismiss the news, see ''El Movimiento Católico'' 19.02.97, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0025564907&page=2 here]</ref> The wildest rumor had it that his son was to command a new Carlist unit.<ref> ''La Correspondencia Militar'' 14.09.99, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001832401&page=3 here]; it was soon corrected that the man in question was Santa Cruz’ nephew, ''Heraldo de Madrid'' 14.09.99, availavle [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000433595&page=2 here]. Even the foreign press speculated that "exploits of the famous and bloodthirsty priest Santa Cruz would doubtless be imititated by many gentlemen of his sacred calling", James Roche, ''The Outlook for Carlism'', [in:] ''The North American Review'' 168/511 (1899), p. 742</ref> A monument was erected in Enderlaza to honor the executed carabineros.<ref>a modest monument was first erected in 1907, replaced with a larger contruction in 1913, Mikelatz 2016</ref>
In 1897 Santa Cruz appeared in ''Paz en la guerra'' by [[Miguel de Unamuno]] and for some 20 years he kept featuring in greatest works of Spanish literary Modernism. In 1906 he was treated somewhat more extensively in ''Sonata de invierno'' by [[Ramón Valle-Inclán]],<ref> the key protagonist was another Carlist, Marqués de Bradomin; Santa Cruz was mentioned in passing</ref> in 1908 in ''[[:es:Zalacaín el aventurero|Zalacaín el aventurero]]'' by [[Pio Baroja]], and in 1909 in two subsequent novels of Valle-Inclán, ''El resplandor de la hoguera'' and ''Gerifaltes de antaño'';<ref> interesting comments in Ernest Augustus Boyd, ''Studies from Ten Literatures'', New York 1925, p. 94</ref> in the latter he was one of the two key protagonists. Finally, in 1918 Baroja dedicated him a set of essays ''El cura Santa Cruz y su partida''.<ref>Baroja wrote ''El cura Santa Cruz y su partida'' upon the false news that Santa Cruz had died in Colombia, Juan Van Halen, ''Baroja y la historia'', [in:] Pio Baroja, ''Juan van Halen'', Madrid 1998, {{ISBN|9788441404069}}, p. 15</ref> [[File:Portrait of Pío Baroja.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Pio Baroja]]]] The role assigned to Santa Cruz by all 3 giants of Spanish literature differed. Baroja from his [[Nietzschean]] perspective portrayed Santa Cruz as a little man who disguised his inferiority with cruelty and epitomized "double barbarity of being a Catholic and a Carlist".<ref> Juan Carlos Ara Torralba, ''Pérez Galdós y Baroja frente al carlismo'', [in:] ''Imagenes en carlismo en las artes'', Estella 2009, {{ISBN|9788423532278}}, p. 37</ref> In case of Unamuno it is believed that Santa Cruz stood for inflexible model of orthodoxy, be it religious, political or otherwise, a model which was valid only within a set of parameters; Unamuno rejected it and presented the Spanish self as a result of dialectic interaction.<ref>"El rol del cura Santa Cruz al apoyar tanto al lado carlista como el lado católico y en interesarse sólo en su propia grey creyente destaca el papel inherente de una religión oficial como determinante sociológico de las creencias y del grupo en boga ... El cura, en este caso, siente que él tiene el derecho de fijar la ortodoxia cristiana además de añadir exigencias violentas para los fieles, reduciendo —según él— la salvación solamente a los seguidores de su autoridad. Su deseo de sólo atender a quienes aceptan sus mandatos limita aún más el concepto de la salvación universal de Cristo. Posiblemente, el rechazo del adolescente Unamuno a esa bomba fratricida, disfrazada de cristiana, haya sido semilla de su futuro desencanto con una religión vista como manipulación al servicio del poder o de prestigios personales y partidistas", Kevin Fagan, ''La libertad de conciencia en Miguel de Unamuno'', [in:] ''Alpha'' 29 (2009), p. 293. Some authors claim that Santa Cruz inspired Unamuno to write his late "nivola", ''San Manuel Bueno, Martír'', a piece which allegedly presents the title protagonist as almost a saint, Celis Alban 2003. In fact, the title protagonist is an exemplary priest serving his community to the utmost; eventually it is revealed that he did not believe in God</ref> Even more complex is the vision of Valle-Inclán. Some claim that Valle-Inclán presented dominant and at times even monstrous personalities of the past to confront them with meager men populating contemporary Spain.<ref> Biruté Ciplijauskaité, ''Configuraciones literarias del Carlismo'', [in:] Stanley G. Payne (ed.), ''Identidad y nacionalismo en la España contemporánea, el Carlismo, 1833-1975'', Madison/Madrid 1996, {{ISBN|8487863469}}, p. 62</ref> Others maintain that Valle-Inclán intended to evoke the atmosphere of ominous drama with satanic personalities.<ref> Leda Schiavo, ''Historia y novela en Valle-Inclán'', Madrid 1980, p. 29, referred after Ciplijauskaité 1996, p. 62</ref> Whatever their intentions were, the [[Generation of '98|noventayochistas]] and especially Baroja transformed a somewhat crude newspaper version of Santa Cruz into a powerful literary image enriched with diabolic and demonic features. This image persisted well into the 1930s,<ref>see e.g. references to Santa Cruz as jackal or hyena, ''Diario de Almeria'' 23.01.34, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2134342&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> at times enhanced with new threads, e.g. this of "cura fascista".<ref>''El Liberal'' 17.06.36, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000082142&interno=S&posicion=5&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In the [[Francoist Spain]] the anti-Liberal stand of El Cura rendered cultivation of the black legend hardly feasible.<ref> Santa Cruz rather seldom featured in the press of 1940-1975, compare ''prensahistorica'' service, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/estaticos/contenido.cmd?pagina=estaticos/presentacion here]</ref> After [[Spanish transition to democracy|transición]] it was already a forgotten past which hardly elicited emotions;<ref>for contemporary cartoon version of the black legend see a sample [http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_9y-KqwVm4No/Srtd9tLJZYI/AAAAAAAAAVQ/swORet61_yE/s320/comic2.jpg here]</ref> if so, they were much more ambiguous.
==White legend== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] Carlism initially ignored Santa Cruz.<ref> though liberal press referred to Santa Cruz whenever a threat of new Carlist unrest seemed looming, the movement did not accommodate Santa Cruz as a role model. He was missing in books listing heroes, claimants and commanders of the past, in leaflets and icononography featuring current political leaders, or in periodicals, see e.g. Francisco de Paula, ''Album de Personajes Carlistas con sus Biografias'', vols. I-III, Barcelona 1888, or B. de Artagan [Reynaldo Brea], ''Políticos del carlismo'', Barcelona 1912,</ref> Re-calibrating the movement as "party of order", until late [[Restoration (Spain)|Restoration]] Traditionalist politicians viewed him as inconvenient ghost from their past.<ref> in 1890 the party leader [[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|Márques de Cerralbo]] declared "no somos ni el cura Santa Cruz, ni Rosa Samaniego. Somos capaces de moralizar la administracion pública con nuestras doctrinas y procedimientos", Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012, p. 233</ref> Things changed upon his death.<ref> the death of Santa Cruz was acknowledged in the Spanish press with information on his humble missionary activity prevailing. Already in the early 1920s he enjoyed somewhat more favorable treatment, e.g. some newspapers referred a letter he allegedly sent to the parish priest of his native village, - ''La Noche'' 24.11.24, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000379222&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here], or in 1926 floated rumors about his penitent pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela, ''Las Provincias'' 14.08.26, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000308599&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]. A contemporary historian claims that "la muerte y el supuesto periplo de su alma [in 1920s he was referred in relation to a widely publicised mystic vision of a visionary Benita Aguirre] coincidiran, en todo caso, con una variacion muy significativa en el curso y en el tono de la literatura sobre su [Santa Cruz'] personaje", Canal 2000, p. 181</ref> Late 1920s saw three apologetic works,<ref> which led some papers to conclude that "rigurosa revisión histórica" was ongoing, ''La Correspondencia de Valencia'' 17.09.32, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000247071&interno=S&posicion=4&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> two flavored with Carlism; [[:eu:Gaëtan Bernoville|Bernoville]]<ref> Gaetan Bernoville, ''La Croix de Sang. Histoire du Curé Santa Cruz'', Paris 1928; it was translated the same year into Spanish and published as ''La Cruz Sangrienta. Historia del Cura Santa Cruz'', San Sebastián 1928 (308 pages)</ref> focused on Catholic regionalism while [[Juan Olazábal Ramery|Olazábal]]<ref> Juan Olazábal y Ramery, ''El Cura Santa Cruz guerillero'', Vitoria 1928 (680 pages)</ref> on [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrism]];<ref> the uncritical account of Santa Cruz, especially the one by Bernoville, was repelled by a Carlist [[Julio de Urquijo e Ibarra|Julio Urquijo]] in ''La Cruz de Sangre. El Cura Santa Cruz. Pequeña rectificación histórica'', San Sebastián 1928 (62 pages)</ref> the third one by [[:es:Nicolás Ormaechea|Orixe]] advanced [[Basque people|Basque]] threads.<ref> it was written in Basque and its decared purpose was pedagogical, to teach the Basques their past: "Santa Cruz’en berri ematen dun liburua ikusi ezkero, erriak gogotik elduko diola nago, ta eskeraz irakurtzea zaila bada era ... oituko al dire euskaldunak irakurtzen", referred after Gorka Aulestia, ''The Basque Poetic Tradition'', Reno 2000, {{ISBN|9780874172836}}, p. 73</ref> Confrontational political milieu of the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] helped the Carlists to re-claim Santa Cruz,<ref>Canal 2000, p. 182</ref> e.g. in poetry,<ref>a Carlist poet [[:es:Ignacio Romero Raizábal|Ignacio Romero Raizabal]] dedicated a poem to Santa Cruz, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 07.06.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000526017&page=3&search=%22cura+santa+cruz%22&lang=es here]. Santa Cruz occasionally featured in poetry also earlier on, referred to evoke the atmoshphere of heroism and savagery, see ''O Cura Santa Cruz'' by a Brasilian-Portuguese poet [[Gonçalves Crespo]], Pedro Nava, ''Chão de ferro'', vol. 3, Sao Paulo 2001, {{ISBN|9788574800226}}, p. 131</ref> and upon outbreak of the [[Spanish Civil War|civil war]] Traditionalist press linked military virtues of [[Requetés]] to these of El Cura.<ref> ''Pensamiento Alavés'' 26.03.38, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000035420&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagin here]a</ref> The Enderlaza monument was blown up by Carlist troops advancing from Navarre to Gipuzkoa in [[Spanish coup of July 1936|July 1936]],<ref> Mikelatz 2016</ref> but got silently reinstated in 1940.<ref> this time with no reference to perpetrators. It is not clear who ordered the monument to be re-erected, some authors suspect it was the work of some local military commander, Mikelatz 2016</ref> Two major Carlist historiographical works, written by [[Román Oyarzun Oyarzun|Oyarzun]] in the 1940s<ref>Roman Oyarzun, ''Historia del carlismo'', Madrid 1969 [subsequent edition], pp. 330-335. Santa Cruz was presented as a rebelious and non-disciplined follower who caused more harm than good to the cause; he is deemed ultimately responsible for atrocities committed by his unit, though direct blame is laid on his lieutenants Frasku and Corneta, genuinely evil personalities</ref> and by [[Melchor Ferrer Dalmau|Ferrer]] in the 1950s, approached El Cura with caution.<ref> Melchor Ferrer, ''Historia del tradicionalismo español'', vols. XXIV-XXV, Sevilla 1958</ref> In popular propaganda there were cases of exaltation<ref> at times Cura Santa Cruz featured on equal footing with iconic Carlist personalities of the highest rank, like Carlos VII, Zumalacárregui or doña Margarita, see José Angel de Igarzabal, ''Acto cultural en Azcoitia'', [in:] ''Montejurra'' 12 (1965), p. 22</ref> yet Santa Cruz did not become an orthodox mythical hero.<ref> the most popular and best-selling Carlist review ''[[Montejurra (magazine)|Montejurra]]'', published in the 1960s, ran a section on history of Carlism. Not a single time Santa Cruz was featured as its protagonist</ref> Youths from the progressist faction of [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]] tried to re-claim El Cura, and in the early 1970s their terrorist organisation [[:es:Grupos de Acción Carlista|GAC]] declared that "the flag of Santa Cruz has been raised again".<ref> Jeremy MacClancy, ''The Decline of Carlism'', Reno 2000, {{ISBN|9780874173444}} , p. 165</ref> Today Santa Cruz marginally features on some private Carlist websites.<ref>see e.g. ''Dos reliquias históricas del célebre guerrillero carlista Cura Santa Cruz han llegado a España'', [in:] ''TradicionViva'' service 13.04.15, available [http://www.tradicionviva.es/2015/04/13/dos-reliquias-historicas-del-celebre-guerrillero-carlista-cura-santa-cruz-han-llegado-a-espana/ here]. Perhaps the site which most closely follows the Carlist Santa Cruz legend is ''ElBandidoRealista'' service, which in its iconographic layer is heavily based on mass-culture-adopted visual references to Santa Cruz, see e.g. ''Contra todos'', [in:] ''ElBandidoRealista'' service 28.04.09, available [http://elbandidorealista.blogspot.com/search/label/Cura%20Santa%20Cruz#!/tcmbck here]. [[Sixto Enrique de Borbon]], who styles himself as a Carlist "standard-bearer", visited the village of San Ignacio in 2005, ''Un príncipe que vino a comer cuy en Pasto'', [in:] ''El Tiempo'' 20.02.05, available [http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1688463 here]</ref> [[File:X borroka.jpg|thumb|160px|''Fight is the way'', or is it? nationalist murale in [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]]]] In vasco-navarrese area the Carlist social base was gradually taken over by [[Basque nationalism]].<ref> Santa Cruz was Basque and he spoke the Gipuzkoan Basque dialect as his mother tongue; also members of his unit were almost all Basques. Basque was the language of command and all communication; if any soldier spoke Spanish he had to excuse himself, José Ignacio Finez García, ''Fuerismo tradicionalista y nacionalismo vasco'' [PhD thesis Universidad Salamanca], Salamanca 2013, p. 44</ref> Its radical faction attempted to re-format the image of Santa Cruz accordingly;<ref>non-violent factions of Basque nationalism also claimed the memory of Santa Cruz, see e.g. the entry dedicated to El Cura and his reception in Eugenio Ibarzábal Aranberri, ''Días de ilusión y vértigo. 1977-1987'', Bilbao 2016, {{ISBN|9788491091516}}</ref> violence and fanaticism were converted into virtues.<ref> Santa Cruz was presented as sort of gudari avant la lettre, Gaizka Fernández Soldevilla, ''Ecos de la Guerra Civil. La glorificación del gudari en la génesis de la violencia de ETA (1936-1968)'', [in:] ''Bulletin d’Histoire Contemporaine d’Espagne'' 49 (2014), p. 253</ref> El Cura started to feature in nationalist propaganda as a convenient hyperbole for violent action; in the 1980s a [[Herri Batasuna]] newspaper ''[[Egin (newspaper)|Egin]]'' ran a series of lengthy articles on El Cura and no nationalist figure dared to criticize him.<ref> MacClancy 2000, p. 236</ref> As a result, papers noticed "admiration of left-wing youth for legendary Santa Cruz"<ref>"admiración que sienten muchos jóvenes de izquierda por el legendario cura Santa Cruz", ''Caro Baroja denuncia los peligros del sincretismo cultural vasco'', [in:] ''El País'' 17.03.81, available [https://elpais.com/diario/1981/03/17/cultura/353631610_850215.html here]</ref> and [[Pío Caro Baroja|Baroja]] observed that "you can meet Cura Santa Cruz on any Basque street today".<ref>Paddy Woodworth, ''The Basque Country: A Cultural History'', London 2012, {{ISBN|9781908493224}}, available [https://books.google.es/books?id=Pbu_BAAAQBAJ&pg=PT98&lpg=PT98&dq=cura+santa+cruz+ETA&source=bl&ots=q3si0th3U1&sig=NlTq7NN2gTWkXZ0bvomaFNCPIKI&hl=pl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiV47eTnaPaAhWhQpoKHaBIC9M4ChDoAQgnMAA#v=onepage&q=cura%20santa%20cruz%20ETA&f=false here]. In the mid-1990s the press noticed a phenomenon of "santacrucismo urbano" among the Basque youth, José Antonio Ayestaran Leguona, ''Santacrucismo urbano'', [in:] ''El País'' 13.07.95, available [https://elpais.com/diario/1995/07/13/opinion/805586408_850215.html here]</ref> The vision of El Cura as spiritual embodiment of "these mountains", unforgiving but idealistic, was pursued in a 1990 Basque film of José Tuduri.<ref>''Santa Cruz, el cura guerrillero'' (1 h 33 mins), see [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102839/fullcredits/?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm filmweb]; in the film Santa Cruz was dissociated from Carlism and presented as independent war leader guided by religious principles; the Carlists were presented as wealthy aristocratic señoritos. The film closes with commentary about the mountains which have always resisted the foreigners, see ''Santa Cruz, el cura guerrillero'', [in:] ''YouTube'' service, available [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p88ZsRKvYJQ here]. The film was not received well by the pundits and was a commercial success neither, ''Santa Cruz el Cura Guerrillero'' entry, [in:] ''Aunamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'' service, available [http://aunamendi.eusko-ikaskuntza.eus/es/santa-cruz-el-cura-guerrillero/ar-106405/ here]</ref> Also a Basque historiographical study by [[:eu:Xabier Azurmendi|Xabier Azurmendi]]<ref> Xabier Azurmendi, ''El cura Santa Cruz'', Bilbao 1986; some sources claim that Azurmendi merely edited the work, written by Ignacio Ariztimuño, see ''Euskonews'' service, available [http://www.euskonews.com/0613zbk/efem61302es.html here]</ref> set the protagonist deeply against the Basque background. Today Santa Cruz is still present in nationalist discourse and features on some websites, usually flavored with radical Left-wing politics.<ref>see e.g. Borrokagaraia, ''El cupo. Antes integrista religioso que vendido autonomista'', [in:] ''Borokagaraia'' service 04.05.17, available [https://borrokagaraia.wordpress.com/2017/05/04/el-cupo-antes-integrista-religioso-que-vendido-autonomista/ here], Aitonseme, ''Grandes Guerilleros II: el fundamentalismo anárquico del Cura Santa Cruz'', [in:] ''Soul Guerilla'' service 03.11.15, available [http://soulguerrilla.com/index.php/2015/11/03/grandes-guerrilleros-el-fundamentalismo-anarquico-del-cura-santa-cruz/ here], ''Santa Cruz apaiza Oñati inguruetan'', [in:] ''Ahotsak'' service 22.01.09, available [https://ahotsak.eus/onati/pasarteak/ona-075-006/ here]</ref> In 2008 a Basque band [[:eu:Bizardunak|Bizardunak]] released a song<ref> titled ''Santa Kruz Apaizaren Kondaira'', The Legend of Cura Santa Cruz</ref> which cultivates the Santa Cruz myth; it remains in public circulation with references to [[ETA (separatist group)|ETA]].<ref> compare visual references to ETA militants in ''Bizardunak - santa cruz apaizaren kondaira'', [in:] ''YouTube'' service, available [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LeFO_9r7buE here]; compare also [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ob5mw6xGYes international outcome] </ref>
A new kind of narrative started to emerge in Colombia in the 21st century. Fundación Manuel Santa Cruz Loydi was set up to honor his work for the poor and to preserve his memory as exemplary missionary, who possibly bordered [[sanctity]].<ref> ''Una fundación colombiana reivindica la vida de entrega del Cura Santa Cruz, guerrillero vasco del XIX que vivió durante más de tres décadas en Colombia'', [in:] ''Euskalkutlura'' service 30.12.03, available [http://www.euskalkultura.com/espanol/noticias/una-fundacion-colombiana-reivindica-la-vida-de-entrega-del-cura-santa-cruz-guerrillero-vasco-del-xix-que-vivio-durante-mas-de-tres-decadas-en-colombia-1 here]</ref> The organisation strives to renovate the decayed San Ignacio church.<ref>''Campaña para recuperar capilla del Cura Santa Cruz Loydi'', [in:] ''YouTube'' service, available [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R6jZgOPuBi0&t=545s here], any many similar footage pieces</ref> Its leader, a historian Isidoro Medina Patiño, in 2005 released two versions of another biography, this time focused on his American period;<ref> Isidoro Medina Patiño, ''Don Manuel: el temible cura guerrillero'', Bogota 2005, {{ISBN|9789583372285}}, and Isidoro Medina Patiño, ''Santa Cruz, el cura de la paz'' (e-book), Bogota 2005</ref> he declares that the Santa-Cruz-related "conceptos canonizados de bueno o malo, pueden confundirse o alterarse", yet both versions remain highly apologetic and present a man who spent his life serving the others;<ref> ''Publican en Colombia la segunda edición de una biografía del cura y guerrillero vasco Manuel Santa Cruz Loidi'', [in:] ''Euskalkultura'' service 16.01.07, available [http://www.euskalkultura.com/espanol/noticias/publican-en-colombia-la-segunda-edicion-de-una-biografia-del-cura-y-guerrillero-vasco-manuel-santa-cruz-loidi here]</ref> for similar role in Jamaica he is also acknowledged in Catholic encyclopedia.<ref> in a scholarly history of the Jamaica Jesuits Santa Cruz is not mentioned a single time, see Wirtenberger 1942, but is acknowledged in online New Catholic Encyclopedia, compare ''Jamaica, the Catholic Church in'' entry, [in:] ''New Catholic Encyclopedia'' online service, available [https://www.encyclopedia.com/religion/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/jamaica-catholic-church here]</ref>
