{{Infobox officeholder | name = Uzziel Ndagijimana | office = Minister of finance and economic planning | nationality = Rwandan | office3 = Chairman of the board of Afreximbank | successor3 = [[Kemi Adeosun]] }}'''Uzziel Ndagijimana''' is a Rwandan economist. He is the current minister of finance and economic planning of Rwanda.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://mobile-reuters-com.cdn.ampproject.org/v/s/mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKBN1HE08H?amp_js_v=a2&amp_gsa=1&usqp=mq331AQCCAE=#referrer=https://www.google.com&amp_tf=From%20%251$s&ampshare=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-rwanda-economy/rwandas-president-names-new-finance-minister-in-reshuffle-idUSKBN1HE08H|title=Rwanda's president names new finance minister in reshuffle|work=Reuters|access-date=2018-07-23}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.minecofin.gov.rw/index.php?id=12&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=665&cHash=037640c4bf62c4aca3044121e01d7128|title=Minister Uzziel Ndagijimana takes over at MINECOFIN, calls for continued collaboration|website=www.minecofin.gov.rw|language=en|access-date=2018-07-23}}</ref>
== Career == Ndagijimana started his career as a lecturer in the faculty of Economics, Social Sciences and Management at the [[National University of Rwanda]] in 1999. In 2002, he moved to leadership positions of the Government of Rwanda.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://live.worldbank.org/experts/uzziel-ndagijimana|title=Uzziel Ndagijimana|date=2018-04-12|work=World Bank Live|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en}}</ref>
He served as the Rector of School of Finance and Banking in [[Kigali]], [[Rwanda]] from 2002 to 2007 after which he moved on to be the Vice Rector of the National University of Rwanda from 2007 to 2011.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theigc.org/person/uzziel-ngagijimana/|title=Uzziel Ngagijimana - IGC|work=IGC|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en-GB}}</ref>
He was the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Health, Republic of Rwanda from May 2011 to July 2014.<ref name=":3" /> He was also the Minister of State in charge of Economic Planning in the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning (MINECOFIN).<ref name=":1" />
During the annual general meeting of [[African Export–Import Bank|Afreximbank]] in [[Abuja]] to commemorate it's 25th anniversary, [[Kemi Adeosun]], Nigeria's finance minister succeeded Ndagijimana as chairman of the board of the bank<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.today.ng/business/finance/kemi-adeosun-elected-afreximbank-board-chairperson-132840|title=Kemi Adeosun elected Afreximbank board chairperson {{!}} TODAY.NG|date=2018-07-14|work=TODAY.NG|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
On April 7, 2018, he was appointed Rwanda’s Minister of Finance and Economic Planning by President [[Paul Kagame]].<ref name=":0" />
Uzziel Ndagijimana was a member of the Board of Directors of the National Bank of Rwanda and the Board of Directors of National University of Rwanda. He also served as Chairman of Economic Advisory Council of the President of the Republic of Rwanda.<ref name=":2" />

[[Cincinnati Cyclones]] | position = [[Forward (ice hockey)|Forward]] | shoots = Right | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 2 | weight_lb = 190 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|11|23}} | birth_place = [[Stand Off, Alberta|Stand Off]], [[Alberta]], Canada | draft = Undrafted | career_start = 2012 | career_end = }} '''Winston Day Chief''' (born November 23, 1987) is a [[Canada|Canadian]] professional [[ice hockey]] player. He is currently playing with the [[Wheeling Nailers]] of the [[ECHL]]. ==Playing career== A member of the [[Blackfoot Confederacy|Blackfoot]] [[Kainai Nation]],[http://www.indianz.com/News/2012/007550.asp Indianz.Com > Native Sun News: Rapid City hockey team bridges communities] Day Chief was raised on the [[Blood Indian Reserve No. 148]] in [[Alberta]], Canada.[http://rapidcityjournal.com/sports/local/winston-day-chief-on-the-cusp-of-a-breakout-year/article_6ec767dd-4768-5f1c-9b14-a46952427dfb.html Winston Day Chief on the cusp of a breakout year for the Rapid City Rush] He attended the [[University of Alaska Anchorage]] before enrolling with the [[University of Lethbridge]][http://www.uleth.ca/unews/article/day-chief-sparking-horns-mens-hockey Day Chief sparking Horns men's hockey | UNews] where he played three seasons of CIS hockey with the Lethbridge Pronghorns,[http://english.cis-sic.ca/sports/mice/2011-12/releases/20110928-cw CIS:Bears top Canada West men's hockey coaches’ pre-season poll] scoring 23 goals and 36 assists for 58 points, while earning 88 penalty minutes, in 68 games played. In his final year he was recognized for his outstanding play when he was named to the Canada West All-Stars Roster as competition for the [[Canada men's national junior ice hockey team]].[http://english.cis-sic.ca/sports/mice/2011-12/releases/20111201-38 CIS:Dinos, Horns to take on Canada's WJC entry] On March 27, 2012, Day Chief was signed as an amateur by the [[Rapid City Rush]] then of the [[Central Hockey League]] for their [[2011–12 CHL season|2012]] playoff run.[http://articles.aberdeennews.com/2012-03-28/sports/31252455_1_herreid-selby-area-abbey-fjeldheim-regional-semifinals/5 Scoreboard - March 27, 2012 - Page 5 - Aberdeen American News] He was re-signed by the Rush for the [[2012–13 CHL season|2012–13]] season, but in his third game he broke his shoulder when he slid hard into the boards. Returning to duty after missing two months of play, Day Chief played out the season, impressing Rapid City's head coach [[Joe Ferras]] who described his play as "fearless" saying "He plays hard. He finishes his checks. He's strong on the pucks and he's got great hands for a big man". On August 29, 2013, the Rapid City Rush announced that Day Chief had been retained to play the [[2013–14 CHL season]].[http://www.foxradio.com/sports/professional/rapid_city_rush/justin-sawyer-winston-day-chief-return-the-black-hills/article_568b11a4-10ff-11e3-bc0a-0019bb30f31a.html Justin Sawyer & Winston Day Chief Return the Black Hills - The FOX - KFXS: Rapid City Rush] After 5 seasons within the Rush organization, Day Chief opted to turn to Europe, signing a one-year contract with [[MAC Budapest]] of the [[MOL Liga]] on August 8, 2016. At the conclusion of the 2016-17 campaign with Budapest, Day Chief opted to return to the ECHL, agreeing to a contract with the Cincinnati Cyclones on September 6, 2017.{{citeweb| url = http://cycloneshockey.com/news/2017/09/cyclones-add-offensive-threat-in-day-chief | title = Cyclones add offensive threat in Day Chief | publisher = ''[[Cincinnati Cyclones]]'' | date = 2017-09-06 | accessdate = 2017-09-06}} Winston Day Chief signed a contract with the Wheeling Nailers on October 10, 2018.[https://twitter.com/Nailers_Off_Ice/status/1050144360711512065 Twitter.com: "Now that the secret is “out”, the Nailers have added veteran F Winston Day Chief as well as Heavyweight Brad Drobot."] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{icehockeystats}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Day Chief, Winston}} [[Category:1987 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alaska Anchorage Seawolves men's ice hockey players]] [[Category:Ice hockey people from Alberta]] [[Category:Blackfoot people]] [[Category:Cincinnati Cyclones (ECHL) players]] [[Category:Cowichan Valley Capitals players]] [[Category:First Nations sportspeople]] [[Category:Rapid City Rush players]] [[Category:University of Lethbridge alumni]] [[Category:Wheeling Nailers players]]

{{BLP sources|date=April 2010}} '''Evgeniy Aleksandrovich Zhovtis''' Евгений Александрович Жовтис (born 17 August 1955) is a [[Kazakhstan human rights]] activist and director of the Kazakhstan International Bureau for Human Rights and Rule of Law.
After graduating as a mining engineer, he became vice president of the Independent Trade Union of Kazakhstan and represented the interests of miners, who worked under often inhumane conditions. He also became a member of the executive board of the [[Civic Organisation Memorial]], working for public awareness of human rights and democratic values under the repressive conditions in the [[USSR]].
After the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]] and independence for Kazakhstan in 1991, Zhovtis continued working for human rights and qualified as a lawyer to help that work. In 1992, with the support of the [[Union of Councils for Jews in the Former Soviet Union]], he founded the Kazakhstan American Bureau on Human Rights and Rule of Law. This later became an independent organisation under its present name.
==Personal life==
Zhovtis is married, with a daughter and a son.
===Conviction=== While driving near [[Almaty]] in late July 2009, the car Zhovtis was driving accidentally hit and killed a pedestrian. On 3 September 2009 Zhovtis was found guilty and sentenced to four years' imprisonment on charges of manslaughter. Local and international human rights activists say the trial was flawed and used by the authorities as a convenient way to imprison him.<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2009/09/03/kazakhstan-review-rights-defender-s-harsh-sentence Human Rights Watch call for his 2009 sentence to be reviewed retrieved 4th Feb 2010]</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/robert-amsterdam/kazakhstans-human-rights_b_276759.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Robert | last=Amsterdam | title=Kazakhstan's Human Rights Drop Through the Floor | date=3 September 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/05/world/asia/05kazakh.html|title=Sentence for Kazakh Activist in Accident Draws Outcry|author=Michael Schwirtz|date=4 September 2009|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=12 April 2010}}</ref> After two and a half years in prison, Zhovtis was granted amnesty on 17 February 2012.<ref name="ifex">{{cite news | title = ALERT: Editor Igor Vinyavsky released | date = 23 March 2012 | url = http://www.ifex.org/kazakhstan/2012/03/23/vinyavsky_released/ | work = [[International Freedom of Expression Exchange]] | accessdate = 2012-12-29}}</ref>
